EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Like Factorio but 3d -- that is, a logistics based game where the point is to mine resources and automate processes to form those resources into productive assets, but in three dimensions. The game is still in Early Access and there's still a ways to go on it but in its current state, its still quite fun (presuming you like logistics, production, and automation). I highly recommend it!

I'm now going to quibble about small things because that's what I do when I like a game: There seems to be a lack of biodiversity in interactable flora and fauna. The end game seems to be almost exclusively about production lines with a lot of great ideas feeling undervalued -- Factorio's bug colonies feel like an appropriate solution, albeit taken (though manning the walls and setting up flame turrets sounds super cool in a game like this). The multiple start zones are just different spots on the same planet and the difficulty levels are misleading (personally, the "hardest" ones seem the easiest and vice-versa). Power generation feels.. clunky -- I can produce a huge facility that should double my power production but the spikes in usage and the finickiness of the water pumps take an overly large amount of effort to smooth out. Not a whole lot of point in exploring (which gets back to great ideas feeling underused/wasted -- like, there's some really cool vehicles). Multiplayer continues to have glitches.

All in all, I'm excited to see what they end up doing -- hopefully updates sooner rather than later.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is truly SATISFACTORY *wink* *wink*. But actually, it's a quite enjoyable game. The creatures are fascinating, I'm thankful for the arachnophobia mode, and the game is easy to just start up and play. It also doesn't require internet! (and if it does, it doesn't require a good signal.) I thought the game was very slow at the toturial segment, but the actual game is quite easy once you have all of your machines set up. It is definitely worth the $20, and I think would be worth it for up to $60!! If you're looking at it, you either will love it or not like this type of game :/

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
After the fun i have been getting with dyson sphere program which 3rd person wider angle, i also now sucked into this other "logistics base building open world' game early access as well but i find much more my style. Mostly because it actually first person so instead of hovering above you are on the ground, the structures are above you, you have jump climb and parkour around your constructions. For early access is very clean from bugs, lots of hours of game play to do, there is early access PVE but the wildlife is no pushover. This has a very familiar ARK Survival Evolved feel to it the experience within the open world, base building, tech research is very similar but does not appear to be using the ARK engine. Even better you can co op with someone else, so work within the map build out the enviroment. I am going to be playing for sometime methinks. The game as is already worth the $$$ i reckon and there is a lot of content within the map already coded that is not yet useful or able to engage which indicates there is a lot more to come.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is in early access but the game is relaxing and you get to build cool things. The number of things you need get a little out of hand. Like to make the 500 Smart Plates for the Space Elevator took 16,000 Screws. Maybe shrink that number to half or speed up the default construction rate and lower the times you have to up the progress bar so it doesn't take so long even with automation and manual combined. The game is fantastic and I definitely recommend it.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is incredibly satisfying for the OCD in me. Plenty of space for creativity and straight up ingenuity.

However!!!
I found the wildlife to be annoying and impractical in relation to the environment. Some have ridiculously unlimited chemical like fireballs and all of them will always attack you. Few predators will attack 100% of the time. Most will always put on a show to avoid conflict for that matter. But these ones come after you fearlessly 100% of the time. All in an effort to guard minerals or crashed drones? The AI needs serious work.

End Thought,
If you add a few smart Mods to this game, you can have hours of endless amusement. So, if you are creative and LOVE to build, but find wildlife and indestructible gas tubes to be annoying. MOD it !

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I don't want to just compare this game to Factorio, but I feel like I have to. In Factorio, I'm continually expanding my factory, and the way upgrades work steers me toward progressively introducing a new challenge and automating the one that I just solved. In Satisfactory, it feels like I know what I want to do, but the game is trying to stop me from having too much fun right away. All of the resources I need are too far away, I can't passively craft things from my inventory while walking around (like I can in Factorio), power sources are very limited early on in the game, alien enemies and health regen severely limit your ability to explore for the first several hours, and on and on. It leads to a whole lot of waiting around for things to happen, because the game puts too many obstacles in your way in the early game for you to continually automate away that tedium. Maybe it gets better later, or maybe the game just did an exceptionally poor job of steering me toward the right way to play the game, but the sheer act of making a factory in 3D space doesn't make up for the tedium introduced here.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Coffee Stain Studios brings objects alive in a way that I just love. The machinery with all the amazing animations just blows my mind for some reason. I love how interactable all the machines feel and how much control over the whole experience you have. I figured 169.0 hours was a good place to stop and write a review for this amazing game that is still in early access.

I have still not gotten past tier 5 because getting coal power up and running was difficult and time consuming for me. Advancing into steel and other actually complicated recipes is where I kinda got stumped with all the ratios and making sure that I'm making enough of the newest thing that I don't have to wait forever to get the to the next tier. this is where you need to start scaling up to what I find is an intimidating degree.

If I have any negatives about the game it's that the world feels really lonely there isn't a whole lot going on in the world, and I don't mean the world looks bad it's a very pretty alien planet but its pretty much just there to look at. No pollution to worry about no terrain deformation, there is some caves to explore and things to find but it just feels lacking. None of my friends own the game so I'm kind of forced to make my own fun with the game and decide on my own what to work on next. And the big bean creature's animation are a little lacking for me, it kinda folds in on itself at its joint areas and I don't like it, it just seams off compared to all the other creatures. Of witch there are 4 enemies I have come across and 4 passive creatures that I came across. apart from the spiders and lizard doggo they are kind of boring.

There is currently 8 tiers of tech in the game and I believe it will go up to 12 by full release. What they will add to those new tiers though I'm not sure as the game seems to have everything I can think of beyond some expansion to the power like some logic so I can have fun some of the stuff that currently just serves as cosmetic's. they just added drone's, zip lines, some power improvements, lights and a hand full of other things I have yet to get to.

All in all it is a great game so far a solid 8/10 for me I cant wait to spend another 169 hours just moving up two more tiers and I cant wait to see what they will add and that they will change.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Overall: 4/5
Satisfactory is primarily about automation, ratios, and building, with minor elements of exploration and creative expression.

Gameplay 4/5
When committing to playing a well-done automation factory game, you first have to know what you’re getting yourself into. These games generally involve a lot of math and ratios (although you technically can play without worrying about that much, as I initially did myself). They are also known for being extremely time consuming and addictive; not in a “Haha oh man I played for HOURS” kind of way but more like an “Oh crap it’s 4 in the morning and I forgot to eat dinner” kind of way.
Both Satisfactory and Factorio also have a plethora of well done QoL features that generally put them a tier above most other games in any genre.

Difficulty/Learning Curve 4/5
If you are into this kind of a game, the learning curve is implemented very well and is quite gradual. You slowly build up to a larger and larger scale, in a more multiplicative kind of way rather than an additive way. However, due to some major difficulty jumps that are inevitable in this type of a game (I’m looking at you, crude oil processing), I can’t give it a perfect score.
The game also feels like it deals with by-products a lot more than its counterparts, but that is easily balanced out with the AWESOME-Sink.


Once there is enough content available for an automation game, the replay values become insane. Satisfactory is no exception. At the time of this review, I have 250 hours played, and that’s completely vanilla and mostly singleplayer. I could easily spend another 250+ playing modded or in a multiplayer game if I wanted to, or I could just keep scaling up the desert factory that I’ve already built.


Satisfactory is very visually pleasing and is actually optimized quite well despite having so much for your GPU/CPU to load once your factory grows larger. However, it has been in early access for a few years, so the graphics are oh-so-slightly dated (possibly a design choice to minimize demand on your PC).


Satisfactory has an extremely well done UI that is easy to navigate.
DO NOT SLEEP ON THE TO-DO LIST!!
Also, don’t sleep on the “hit x” feature to open up the encyclopedia.


The control set is pretty standard and will feel familiar to most gamers. Using “c” to crouch/slide felt weird at first, but I got used to it, and it can always be rebound.
There are some minor issues with the controls, such as the hoverpack feeling like it should have a “move in the direction of the crosshair” option.
Crouch sliding constantly to go faster, however, is a very awkward mechanic.
No autorun WHY??


The audio doesn’t stand out as exceptional, but it also doesn’t really fall short. The music is fitting and is quite nice, but isn’t quite as masterful and immersive as say, Astroneer or Divinity’s music.
The machine audio is also really cool, and they do a good job with ADA’s voice, but it’s not the kind of game that I found myself turning the audio, like I did with the aforementioned games.
I would generally be playing the game with a show or video going on in the background, so I wasn’t as interested and invested in the audio or immersion in general.


Early on, the game has an extremely well done atmosphere, and I would have probably given it a 5/5 if it stayed that way.
As you progress, you focus much more on the factory itself and feel less involved with the alien world around you. You can always go exploring, but that is truly a minor part of the game compared to building and automation. This brings a new kind of atmosphere: the atmosphere of the well-oiled and fine-tuned machine (or absolute spaghetti mess) that is your factory.


Unfortunately, Satisfactory’s storyline is currently very underdeveloped, but for very good reasoning. If you start a new game and don’t skip the intro, there is absolutely a story present, but it falls off heavily after that.
My strong personal belief is that this is because story is an absolute bottom tier priority when it comes to automation based games. Having a great story is a welcome addition to any game, but no one is picking up Factorio or Satisfactory and saying “Man, I REALLY loved the creative story writing in that game!” They are almost always talking about the gameplay aspects such as the amazingly well done UI and QoL features, ratios, math, etc.


The combat system is minimal and sub-par. You get a weapon, you dodge enemy attacks if necessary, and you poke them to death. There is a nailgun, but I never really used it.
Combat is a very low priority in a game like this, so in my honest opinion, it is slightly irrelevant when it comes to my overall impressions of the game.
The crafting system on the other hand is very well done.
It can be a little tedious at times, but this is likely a gameplay design intended to discourage hand crafting and encourage automation.
The to-do list and “press x” feature make it much easier to handle.
You cannot automate the production of buildings like you can in Factorio and Dyson Sphere Program. This is an intended gameplay design, but I’m not too sure I’m that big of a fan of it. Either way, it was easy to adjust my playstyle to just having various materials on hand rather than carrying various buildings around with me.


Multiplayer is a ton of fun and implemented quite well, but even the devs have said it is still unfinished and unstable. You will likely run into minor issues here and there, such as visual glitches (like the giant item glitch), desync issues, and items disappearing. Overall it’s done quite well and I’ve hardly had any problems, but they do exist, so I can’t give it a 5/5.
Be sure to adjust network quality settings to the highest possible for all players.


The progression system in this game feels very good, excluding a few difficulty hurdles.
You advance pretty steadily and you can definitely feel that advancement as you move on.
You advance similarly to how you build up: in a more multiplicative way than an additive way.
It does start to feel a bit “grindy” towards the end. Progression definitely slows down more and more as you get into the higher tiers, and it can get to be quite tedious and drawn out in the very late game. This absolutely works for some people, and it worked for me up until the very end of the game, where I simply lost interest because I had essentially unlocked everything.


You have to look for the humor in this type of game to find it; it isn’t right in your face, but similarly to Astroneer, it comes mostly from the hilarious possibilities allowed through the physics system. There are all kinds of things you can do to propel yourself and ragdoll your character or even launch yourself into the atmosphere.
There are also subtle little comedic aspects presented through ADA, some of the tooltips, and the funny writings found inside the HUB.
Most of the machines also have funny names that represent their job.

Despite the non-perfect rating, I would not hesitate one bit to highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in math, ratios, automation, production, assembly lines, and factory style games. Even if you aren’t a math person, like yours truly, you can easily adjust your playstyle accordingly and find plenty of joy in this game. Maybe it will even help you discover a love or appreciation for numbers that you never knew was there.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's interesting, for quite a while (300 hours in).

But ultimately it's another grinder; make X widgets with a different formula from the last 30 widgets. At the final level, you need to make 4000 of one widget that is produced at a nominal rate of 1 per minute. Trying to scale that up to a reasonable number requires a simply enormous factory; I think I spent about 20 hours building it before I finally decided that it's just not worth the time spent.

It would be a lot better if the game itself, not mods from random sources, had a copy-and-paste function to help build large structures, instead of making the player make hundreds and thousands of individual components and then connecting them with individual cables (for power) and conveyors (for materials).

There's also no way to manage buildings except by going to them and interacting with them directly.

So, fun for a while in the early game, then mostly tedious.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
TL:DR Summary: If you buy this game it will consume you, as it triggers the same parts of your brain as completing a multi-month hobby project.

Satisfactory...the first game I have ever felt compelled to write a review for. If you are familiar with games like Factorio, Space Engineers, or Dyson Sphere Project, you will have an easier time in your first few hours. Don't worry though, if you are new to this genre, I can not think of a better game to start with. Not necessarily because it's easier than those other games, but because it is by far the most REWARDING.

You begin by choosing a starting location, this is an important choice (ease of building/danger vs. richness of resources) and I would recommend starting in one of the first 2 locations on your first play-through. The nice thing is though, you can visit all of them eventually. The map is HUGE, and I love that no matter where you start, you can end up building in the hardest location later on if you wish. Speaking of the map, WOW, is it gorgeous. You could start in the lush green grassy plains and end up in an unforgiving red canyon hell by the end. There is so much variety to every biome that I was still finding fresh looking areas 30+ hours in. There isn't a lot of variety to the wildlife, but there is enough to keep things interesting.

Moving onto the game-play loop, it starts out simple enough. Mine resources and use those to craft items to craft other things and so on. HOWEVER, it does not stay this stale for very long. Soon you will have automated miners feeding into smelters, which feed into constructors, which build the item resources needed to supply assemblers with 2 different parts to craft another, more complex part. Then you will need to route the end line of this to a SPACE ELEVATOR and send it into orbit. I was in awe with how quickly the scale of my factory grew as I was able to automate more and more of my production...and that's just the first 2 tiers of milestones, there are a total of 8 tiers....and it gets BIG and COMPLEX.

Combat is....meh. Not many things to fight, although what is there provides enough of a challenge. Normally you will find hostile enemies near resources or crash sites (oh yeah btw you can find alternate recipes for items in wrecks...to add to the variety of problem solving tools). You start out with a little taser weapon and can later upgrade that further. There are also a few ranged options, but again, combat is not a focus here.

Graphics are amazing, from the incredible art design for each piece of machinery to the planet itself, eye candy is abundant. What really stood out to me though was the quality of the ANIMATIONS! Wow, some of those animations (like when you first build the space elevator) are insanely impressive.

I'm going to wrap up this review now because I could go on an on, but you should really experience this for yourself. I will end with this though....you can build trains, trucks, buggies, jetpacks, and my fav....HYPERTUBES. There is no end to how creative you can get with your factory.

I cannot believe this is Early Access, best $30 I've ever spent, buy it and lose yourself in the gears of your creation. Also...don't go into caves unprepared :D

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Part of a fairly small subgenre certainly, but it still stands out as a being utterly fantastic at what it does. The "factory game" has always been something I've had a fondness for, and this feels like it being executed with near-AAA scope. It's got a large amount of content and tiers to sort through (Plus more being added), a large world to explore, and a great sense of humour. It being an indie game in early access means what it always means (Plenty of issues), but they have done little to spoil the experience, and some even fit quite well with the game's tone.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
(This game helped me realize how severe my OCD is)

I work as an engineer, and I don't know whenever to laugh or cry about the fact that I come home from working and then sit down and do essentially the same thing... except it is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fun.

Hours and hours just disappear into nothing as I just make increasingly more complex and elaborate schemes for the purpose of automation, and I think that everyone who enjoys the satisfaction of putting something together and go *CLICK* and just watch everything work (OR NOT) will have a blast from playing this game.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I've been a gamer for over thirty years, and now that I've put in nearly 300 hours in Satisfactory and built everything there is to build, I can safely say it's one of my favorite games of all time. It's easily in my top 5, and considering it's still in early access at the time I'm typing this with many more features and improvements yet to come, that's really saying something.

First, don't look at those screenshots of countless machines and mazes of conveyor belts and pipes and think 'omg, this looks way too complicated for me'. Screenshots like those are not the best representation of the game for new players, and they're almost certainly from the late game (or mid-game at the earliest). You're not gonna be at that point for awhile, and Satisfactory actually does a great job of gradually introducing new builds and concepts to you as you progress. You start off with just a few simple things to build and nothing but a little craft bench to build them with, and as you advance through the tiers, you get more and more new parts, machines, and other stuff unlocked. Then, before you know it, you'll have your first automated assembly line making iron plates and rods.

Make no mistake, this is a game that will make you use your noggin a bit. You don't need to be a genius, but there will be times where you'll need to do some math and calculations to maximize efficiency. A simple example: machine A can produce 60 iron ore per minute, machine B turns 30 iron ore per minute into 30 iron ingots per minute. So how many machine B's will you need to utilize the production capacity of machine A? (Answer is two) :) Questions like this will present themselves regularly as you build and expand, and although it certainly gets more complicated than my example (especially in the mid to late game), you should be fine even if you're only halfway decent at basic arithmetic.

Power is another critical part of the game. With the exception of conveyor belts, your machines don't run on magic - they need electricity or else they're useless chunks of metal. To start with, you're given a weak, primitive means of generating power that cannot be automated, and as you experience your first blown fuse (which happens when your power consumption exceeds your power generating capacity) and/or your first power grid shut down because you haven't manually filled it with fuel in the last twenty minutes, you'll start growing tired of it. :) But good news! The second power source you unlock (and all the others after that) generate way more power and can be 100% automated. In other words, if setup right, it'll generate power for you forever without you ever having to think about or touch it ever again. Complete game changer.

Feel like taking a break from the machines and conveyor belts for a bit? That's perfectly fine! In fact, this is encouraged - there's a beautiful, vast world for you to explore with all kinds of surprises and things to find, many of which will be very helpful later on (if not immediately). Just be careful - there are plenty of hazards out there too. This is one of the great things about this game though - you have complete freedom to do whatever you want whenever you want.

You'll encounter little quirks and bugs once in awhile, but they're all minor and don't detract from the experience. Overall the game is very stable, well-built, and runs just as good, if not better than most games NOT in early access. The game is truly fantastic, and once it comes out of early access, I'm very confident it will get nothing but fantastic reviews from all publications. Just look at the Steam reviews - an astounding 97% are positive, and it's completely deserved - this is an amazing game. It's $30 US, yet it's already far better than most $60 AAA games. Coffee Stain Studios have hit a grand slam here.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
SATISFACTORY (genre: factory building)
SCORE: 9/10 (COULD BE HIGHER! UP TO 9.5)
This game is great and you could see this in other reviews as well but the games is still lacking things.
-1st thing, the Production Speed is still IMO, not that fantastic, but it could be based on my personal preference. For me if the production and manufacturing got sped up by 25% I would have been addictive to it.
-2nd thing, the conveyor system is still buggy and can be dug into the ground but it is not a big of a problem for me.
-3rd thing, the power system is not 100% polished and solely based on using products, should add Solar Panels or Wind Turbines in the future.
-4th thing, THE GAME HAVE SO MANY POTENTIAL TO EXPAND EVEN MORE WITH SUCH RESPONSIVE DEVELOPERS team and even though the game is pretty fun right now but imagine this:
*Adding a better economy/trading system in the games, for example building computer rigs to "mine" crypto currencies, the unified currencies of trans solar civilization to trade. Or even to push it further, to have a trans galactic economy system which you could invest in different galactic companies, etc. Holly s* I would be addict to this game if it did have it.
*The planet is beautiful and fun to explore, but not so fun anymore after you've spent sometimes exploring it as it became cliche natural world. Imagine every single planets or areas having their own characteristic to push the players to explore even more. For example, having an outrageous high mountainous areas which reward the players exploring it by finding a cave full of exotic materials near the top of the highest mountain, or slaying Alien Dragons living in the caves for exotic drops. Also adding Giant Alien Beasts with its nest deep in the forest, etc. And trading the rewards getting from slaying such beasts would reward the players greatly. I have saw Coffee Stain having experience in games like Deep Rock Galactic too and IMO, the games could thrive further on the mechanism of exploring and getting rewards from slaying different alien beasts mechanism
*Or even have smart aliens society which are living in their own little settlement or village who would trade with exotic stuffs for your technology.
*This game have so much potential in multiplayer too, having laughed my A* out when I saw my friends screamed at the top of his lungs when he was attacked by those terrifying cave spiders, and you could add many different things in future for the players to mess around, like different clothing, personal gadgets, even more furniture, wall designs, toys, or even board games and billiards for the players in the same server could play with each others.
*I would say as many other players have suggested this idea too, you could even expand the game to space by adding space ships, etc. but for me, I wouldn't push it, because many other games have done this too, and i don't want to lost all of the current characteristic and charm of this game by changing it that way. Those game thrived on player travelling different planets and their planet is very unrealistically small and not complex, but seriously, one planet is way too big already and you could still expand the world on it and I will respect you for being different.
In Conclusion: this game is near 90% polished and could add so many things into the game in the future as it is still in Early Access (The New Oldest Trick in the book huh?) And I am expecting so much more from it.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game was pretty much exactly what I wanted out of it. If you wanted a 1st person factorio with decent graphics this is about as good as its going to get. The constant growth of production chains into more materials is never ending, and even with 45 hours in one game I have yet to even get to some of the mid-higher end items. Creating massive production lines drawing from resources across the map all to a single place to create one single item feels pretty gratifying, and the game definately adds enough customization and choices in how you build your factory to make it truly unique. The map is also big, really big, and pretty diverse so its actually pretty enjoyable to explore. Definitely going to sink many more hours into this game. 10/10

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Pros:
-good graphics
-well designed maps, beautiful + no out of place clipping etc.
-amazing game play, especially if you're mechanically inclined.
-very easy to setup multiplayer, was able to jump right in with no issues.
-no major bugs or glitches that I've had to experience yet.

Cons:
-not very many different maps, which I would assume can cause game play to eventually stagnate. [Edit] At the time of making this I didn't realize there was only one map. But I see now that it is a large single map, with many possibilities. So if it's a negative or not is in the eye of the beholder.

Maybe could add variants of ore etc. to add a splash of variation to the game, but other than that I can't think of anything I dislike.

Overall, I think this game provides a mechanically/statistically challenging environment in a way that still offers the relaxation and entertainment of playing a video game you enjoy. Would definitely recommend. 8.5/10

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is a game where you build factories. (no duh)
Start by mining your resources by hand, then get portable miners to help speed up that process

Sidenote:
I was - Honestly - stunned how good this game looks.
if you don't like factory building or maybe you need a break from it

just explore the beautiful, absolutely gorgeous world.
(I cannot think of enough adjectives to describe this game)
And my 2yo. laptop had barely a problem running it.
At standard graphics settings I got about 40-60 fps

(just a bit jittery though so I turned the shadow
and post-processing quality to high instead of ultra)

Eventually unlocking Miners, Constructors, Smelters
& Conveyor belts to automate your work for you.

Each building has it's own production rates and resource requirements,
Necessitating good Multiplication, Division and Addition skills.

I personally, recommend you to try to achieve maximum efficiency in your buildings.
Not only because I like math
As that will ensure you get as much done as an overproducing factory setup,
But without the increased power consumption with virtually no benefit.
(and more than an under producing factory, obviously)

I've only gotten to tiers 5 or 6 in about 50h
(idk, MeMoRy BaD)
But even with the slow progression I still had lots of fun

I'm hooked on this game lol
Like all my favorite things in one
Space, Math, g-game uh... yummy sounds?

Also there's a not-so hidden easter egg with the Somersloops or mercer spheres...
where if you stand near it for a long enough time you will hear as ADA tries harder and harder
to convince you to pick it up.
Maybe not game changing but, I thought i'd bring it up.
if you want you can try it for yourself. remember you'll need to stand there for about 3-4 minutes to get all the voice lines
You will hear some weird distorted audio that sounds like the vowel A right before she starts to speak.

(at the end she just keeps saying "Harvest, Harvest it, Collect the artifact" or something like that.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
At the time of this review I have finished tiers 6 & 7 and the game is still in early access. My review goes over what I have experienced so some information about the game might not have been available to me. Additionally, the review contains spoilers so read at your own risk:

Satisfactory is the sort of game that at a glance would make you think that it's pretty fun and you wouldn't be wrong to think that. The game features 8 tiers of new and upgraded items, buildings, vehicles and more to help expand your forever-growing factory at the expense of the amount of hours you pour into the game.
What's great about the game is that it's a genre that isn't as popular as your average FPS, Battle Royale or RPG so it was something that peaked my interest straight away (Take into consideration that I've never played another factory game such as Factorio).

A couple hours into the game I was still experiencing new features such as it's pretty large yet lacking map - I chose the grass fields as my starting point due to my first time playing the game: the main reasons of exploring the map are for hard drives unlocking alternate crafting recipes, resources like coal and water (mid-game) for more power, power slugs to boost your factory production however not always efficiency and maybe even leaves if you haven't progressed that far. This may seem like a lot at first but really isn't after going out of your way to get more power slugs for the 80th time. To combat how boring that may become, you are faced with 4 types of creatures: charging dogs, dogs that shoots fireballs (other variants shoot some blue stuff), rotund larvae with wings that emerge from plants and creepy spiders who are by far the scariest to run away from. They all have their mini-boss forms as well which aren't any harder, they just have one extra attack and have more health.

Now for the factory itself, the game's selling point. To progress through the game you must build from resources scattered around the map to manufacture products such as iron rods, screws, copper wire and a whole lot more. As ADA mentions at the start of the game, your objective is to be as efficient as possible and to not waste; in order to do this you must calculate EVERYTHING so that you don't overproduce or underproduce which can cause products to take 100x longer to make. Watching Youtube videos on how to make your factory more efficient is just a waste of money, you might as well not play the game if you're just going to copy someone else. Making mistakes with your placements could potentially mean you have to rebuild your entire factory which sounds like a real pain in the ass because it is. For this reason alone, I wouldn't like to spend more time playing this game just so I can watch more products being made.

In conclusion: This game is fun for the first 30-40 hours but then can get repetitive for most people unless you're into building factories (once again, if you enjoyed or liked factorio then this game is probably for you). I wish to see future updates that improve the amount of content in this game and potentially more features to make the game fun for a wider variety of people. I'll still recommend this game but I wouldn't recommend paying full price right now unless you're confident with the game as it is in its current state or unless you're able to trust the developers of the game to make a good finished game. Personally, I believe Coffee Stain Studios are amazing developers after seeing and playing their other games such as Valheim, Goat Simulator and Sanctum 2.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This may very well be the best game I’ve ever played. Games like this one very rare. I love the concept and execution of the concept of this game. I’ve never left a review for a game before, but this one definitely deserves nothing but positive reviews. I am looking forward anxiously for Update 5. Until then here are my only two suggestions: 1. Make mass building easier. I am currently working on a mega base (75x75 for the base layer) and it took nearly 5 hours just to do the first level. I then installed the SMART mod and it took only 10 seconds to build what before took hours. I think that a change like this would make building less of an obstacle. As the game currently is, building is a hugely unnecessary obstacle for building massive factories. 2. Add a second body slot. Constantly changing between jetpack, blade runners, gas mask, and soon hover pack is excessively aggravating. Body slots are the one thing in the game that never improve, change, or get better. What you start with is what you get.

Overall, despite the two very annoying things I meantioned (which i fixed with mods anyway so it’s fine) I couldn’t reccomend this game enough to anyone who loves open world, building, survival style games. Or anyone who wants to try something new!

The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in “advanced” countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human being to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in “advanced” countries. The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy. If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later. We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can’t predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society. In this article we give attention to only some of the negative developments that have grown out of the industrial-technological system. Other such developments we mention only briefly or ignore altogether. This does not mean that we regard these other developments as unimportant. For practical reasons we have to confine our discussion to areas that have received insufficient public attention or in which we have something new to say. For example, since there are well-developed environmental and wilderness movements, we have written very little about environmental degradation or the destruction of wild nature, even though we consider these to be highly important.

would invade other planets and destroy their Eco system again 10/10

It's the most addictive, brain-teaser and awe-inspiring base building game I've played! I can easily play this game until 2 AM, it's so satisfying (no, really) to see your factory grow from basically nothing. I love the creative features of the game, like the flying manta ray and her puppies, or the giant potato-like buddy that comes to check out new parts of your base. The landscapes are insanely beautiful, I love the pink forest and the waterfalls the most.

A bit of advice: if there's anything that looks like a green cloud of fart, STAY AWAY. It's radiation and you'll lose health! The neatest feature of the game is taming the , who bring you awesome gifts like caterium, power slugs or SAM ore in exchange for head rubs and raspberries.

I've been wanting this game forever, and it does not disappoint! I keep restarting my factory after I've thought of a new, more efficient way of saving space while maximising resources. I would 100% recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a game that takes you on adventures <3

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is not a bad game. But i sure as hell can not recommend it. The high ratings puzzle me. The game is tedious, frustrating and feels like it intentionally slows you down a lot of the time. I'm a big factory building fan, so it's not a problem with the genre. There is a difference between spending 50 hours in Factorio, designing a modular nuclear reactor you can re-use over and over, or spending 50 hours in Satisfactory just placing down stuff manually. For a game about automation, Satisfactory consists of mostly all manual effort.

Factory Building:
A lot of convenient objects and features are missing. No signs to label things. No GUI overlay to help identify which constructor produces what. No junctions for hypertubes. Sorting is not available early-game. No Logic. A lot of little, important things like that. You cant even limit how many items go into a container. Gotta fill the other slots with sticks and stones if you want some additional stacks, but then forget about connecting that container to a belt in the future.
I'm not a fan of clipping objects. "Belt too steep" or "Belt has an invalid shape" are common things to read. So why is it okay for belts to literally clip through each other? This is not an exploit either, simply the default behavior. It causes real problems as well. Sometimes you place things that appear perfectly connected, just to later notice they are not working because the belt goes from A to B while your merger just sits at the perfect location, but attached to the ground instead, with the belt clipping right through it.
And monorail track placement gives me nightmares.


There are basically no convenience features. Nothing you can do to speed up building stuff. Blueprints would be really helpful. But at the very least give us to speed up building. Need a 100x100 concrete platform? That's 10.000 individual object placements and there is nothing you can do about that. Remember this is a factory building game. This is not an exaggerated example.

Let me just name one more example for how problematic this is. A single MK5 belt can transport 780 items per minute. Say we wanted to turn that into iron rods, which happens at a rate of 15 per minute per constructor. That is 780/15 = 52 constructors. Together with about the same amount of splitters, and mergers, a couple douzen power poles or so, and of course the belts to connect it all. Each of which is to be placed manually. But that's not all. The recipe for each individual constructor has to be set individually, inside the GUI of the corresponding constructor. Not just that; every single power line connecting any power poles or consumers, has to be placed manually as well. Every. Single. Powerline. Let that sink in please.


Animations are mostly well done, but pretty long. Usually this is not a problem, except when it is. Loading or unloading a train? That's 25 seconds each. Drones are even worse. But that's fine as those are meant for long distances anyways. What's not fine is that these animations actively lock up the stations. While loading a train, a station does not accept items. While unloading a train, a station does not output items. This seriously messes with calculations. The only proper way to guarantee a constant output is using a container as buffer, which effectively halves the output ports, thus doubles train length and with that the amount of stations required. Did i mention how huge these are? The 100x100 platform example was not an exaggeration, but an understatement.


There is only one map, with four spawns. To be fair the map is quite large and definitely beautiful. This still heavily reduces replay value tho. The ressource distribution, unless randomized, is also questionable. We only had normal and impure ressources around our spawn, leading us to believe pure ressources were quite rare - which would make sense. We then later found huge clusters of pure ressource nodes close to each other. Using boosters on those, they are basically easily enough to fill all your needs - and we are talking about quite a large factory already.
A lot of the problems i have with this game feel like they are intended to slow the player down. Which may be related to just having one single finite map. My biggest complaint about the map however, or rather minimap, is how you . I mean, cmon? There is a huge satisfaction in seeing your factory grow on a global scale, covering large parts of the map. But there is also practical use to this, for planning where train tracks may end, or seeing in a distance where you would connect things together and so on. None of that is possible.


Expect to run . Our starting base A and our later main base B was separated by a good 10 minutes of walking, on a flat and mostly straight path we build for that purpose over the ocean.
We later connected most of the important locations using hypertubes. Using entrances as boosters (likely not intened but fun), you can reach ridiculous speeds and cover the same distance in 20-30 seconds. So what about some place C in the middle? There are no official hypertube junctions. Cmon, who implements a tube network without thinking about junctions? I managed to work something out, but considering how bad high speeds already work in multiplayer, proper junctions shouldnt be an afterthought.


Vehicles suffer from several problems. They are slow, considering the distances. For automation this is fine, for personal travel it's not. Some of them handle extremely unwell. I managed to 180° nose-flip the 6-wheel 10-ton-looking Truck on a flat road with low speeds by hitting a pebble.
Trains were one of my biggest disappointment. With 120 kmh they are the fastest ground based vehicles. For personal travel to feel enjoyable you may as well double that tho. But that's not why they are disappointing to use. Steering is - or rather how you cant do that. Yeah, you read right. In order to change directions you have to brake the train to a full stop, get out of it, manually pull a lever which spawns on junctions to switch "default directions", get back into the train and accelerate again. The animations for accelerating and braking are nice, but it takes soo much time to do so. And as such it is insanely impractical to use trains for anything except a pre-setup path from A to B. The autopilot does not care about the levers, so they basically only exist to annoy and discorage players. Who in their right mind thought this was a good idea?


Let's ignore hand-slots as those are mostly for combat. There is . In this slot you can either equip your "running shoes", jetpack, gas mask or hazmat suit. Did i mention how slow travelling feels? Wouldnt it be nice to have faster movement speed while also being able to slightly float upwards? Or not suffocate in the poison gas covering half the map? Or not die of radiation poisoning when you run past uranium? Every time you encounter one of these situations you have to switch out your current equipment. Which also means you have to carry them all around. Let us combine them. Or give us at least 2 body slots. It's not like these items are OP either. The jetpack only covers a couple vertical meters and needs fuel. The gas mask requires filters, and so on.


Performance is not the best, could be worse tho. Autosaves, once your factory grew enough, just completely freeze the game for a second or two every five minutes. Game crashed a hand full of times in our playthrough. Multiplayer has certain problems, but considering everything else works decent.

Why are you here. Read one of the short one-liners telling you how great the game is. Or read the above.

Most factory games take place as a top-down eagle-eye view but this one is has a first-person view and actually manages to pull it off. EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is a first person version of factorio with some slight differences, the graphics are very very nice, its awesome to see all of the different components and parts speedly rush down a conveyor as you try to work out the best way to get 100% efficiency, this is a really fun game both single and multiplayer for people who enjoy games with automation and i would say it has some puzzle solving elements to it trying to figure out the best combination to get the best efficiency, the basic story is you are a FICSIT employee who has landed on a unknown planet, you are tasked with creating a factory to create parts for a space elevator, as you progress the parts become more complex and you have to venture into deeper and more hostile territory, a nice feature i like is the arachnophobia mode which will turn the spider like creatures into cats which are much more pleasing to look at but it is sad to kill them. I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a nice relaxing automation game thats like factorio but with much better graphics and in the first person. Unlike factorio you do not have to defend your base from alien invaders but who knows this may change in the future as the game is still being updated by the developers.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Great factory game from the viewpoint first person. When you start you feel the need to mine like you would in normal survival but immediately you begin advancements that are all about automation and optimization. The recipes get more complex and the grind needed to advance also increases but so do your choices of automation. The game really opens up when you get your power system automated which allows you more time to explore the very large map.

At the time of writing I have 65 hours of game play and expect that number to hit 100+ in no time at all now that I am trying to complete the final challenges of tech 7 and 8 along with the final elevator mission for early access.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Most people run when they hear Early Access but I have conplete faith this game will be completed.

The discord for the game is active and the Devs often do a twitch stream that is open to questions. They update you on the progress being made and what will come in future updates. The updates offer lots of new content to an already amazing game. The devs take bugs seriously and work to fix them quickly.
The gameplay is addictive and well thought out with good progression. Graphics look pretty good and the gameplay works well for me. It has a simple goal with an infinite amount of possibilities.

Warning there are some weird alien type creatures that roam the planet, some of them make me uncomfortable so if youre bothered easily by those types of things please research them and get familiar before you get the game.

This game will continue to be worked on and will see a full release once the amazing team of devs consider it ready. It deserves a chance and if you don't like it then you can always refund it

It deserves a solid 8.75/10

I don't understand why this game got so popular.

I guess there are people in the world that believe "game" includes performing a trivial task repeatedly without any chance of failure or obstacle to overcome.

For me, I want to fail, I want to be challenged, I want my neurons to fire. The only challenge in this game seems to be the calculation of fractions when you figure the output of one machine and the input of another. Hell, that is barely even there, since most people just use an online tool to do that calculation for them. At any rate, I mastered that skill in second grade, 36 years ago. Your mileage may vary depending on your education system.

I suppose you could build things to be pleasing to the eye, and line it all up with right angles or multiple floors vertically, but why would you? No one is going to see it.

Other than that, I found myself, simply building the same thing, as needed, over and over and over again, with no purpose, no obstacle, and no challenge. The game doesn't even let you save a blueprint, so once you spend three hours lining everything up for item X, you have to do it all over again in another spot when you need more of item X.

It isn't possible to lose at all, and that's a huge turn off for me. It's an exercise of how many times I can do the same thing over hours until boredom prevents me from playing anymore.

I enjoyed Factorio quite a bit more, simply because there was opposition and the possibility of losing. In Satisfactory, both resources and time are infinite. This truly is a game for people to turn off their brains. I want to exercise mine. I have a backyard full of grass I can watch grow if I want to.

I have almost 10 hours on this game and can say a lot about the game so lets start with the best it is a factory survival game on an alien planet however things like food and water are not required unless taking damage by enemies so its very laid back and focuses purely on you engineering absolutely insane factories. the graphics are pretty and the entire landscape is extremely unique, the spec requirements are very low, the game has its bugs but is in beta cost 29.99 and outperforms leading triple A games in entertainment, based on how the games going now theres easily 40-50 hours of base game content for first time players.

The only major cons of the game are its still beta so it has its bugs from clipping terrain to wonky conveyor belts sometimes the visuals are definitely lacking, another massive con is because this game has no other NPCS except for an AI female voice it gets boring normally you would just play multiplayer however after you start getting into the point of coal which is a very early stage the game becomes very buggy in multiplayer so long hours are not something i really see myself doing however if you do just enjoy engineering factories solo thats cool.

Id personally recommend this game to anybody in the market for something new the best deal your gonna get is 23.99 on sale so just pay full price and support the devs you will learn quickly that 6$ was much better spent on this game rather then a big mac :)

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
The game is still incomplete, yet it feels so polished and well-made. Every update brings unique new things and adds a lot of hours to exploration and progressing your factory. The system is very well-made and structurally good as a progression system, and it's very rewarding. The replay-ability is endless, because you can play the game in many different ways, go about things in different ways, you can also make a lot of different factories with different structures the game offers you.

There are different maps, they are all very well designed. Graphics are amazing as well as performance. I also haven't found any major / game breaking bugs that make the game unplayable or straight up broken to the point it's not fun.

Multiplayer is not flawless but really fun together. All around it's a really great game, it has enough combat which is challenging but not overpowering, the progression feels very rewarding and even starting over isn't a big deal because of the variety in things you can do and how you can go about stuff.

I guess you could say that Satisfactory is indeed satisfactory, 9/10, would definitely recommend.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
As a Factorio veteran this game gets an easy recommendation from me. Although I want to say that the emphasis with Satisfactory is on a different part of the factory building experience. Whereas Factorio rewards and almost requires laying out your entire base towards efficient mass-production, Satisfactory is more open towards more relaxed styles of play and building. Veterans may still want to build a single massive mega-factory with all resources coming in on one side to produce every possible product in the game on a main bus system. But at least for a first playthrough I have found it to be very enjoyable to place individual and disjoint factory buildings all over the place, producing individual products where convenient to then later collect them when needed or automate their transport. The foundation, wall and walkway options provided make it possible to create very beautiful factory buildings that nestle into the varied and rugged terrain. Planning and filling out a new factory building is always immensely satisfying for me as it all comes from nothing into a sleek and well-organized production setup.

Unlocking new technologies is paced well and drives forward the process of expansion. Exploration takes more time than in Factorio but feels really great thanks to the beautiful landscapes. Barriers like destructible rock and gas clouds will impede progress until you can build the countermeasures. Finding and exploiting a new resource site will have a big impact and let you advance technologically. Finally, there is always room to automate more and to further increase production of needed resources.

Honestly the only disappointment I had with the game is that there are so few ways to change the natural environment to clear the way for a megafactory. The world is handcrafted and hills can't be flattened to create a flat plain to build your factory on. Hence why it's mostly easier to build smaller separate factories. I like that playstyle very well, but I wish there was the option to just build it all in one place like with Factorio. That being said I have only played on the first map, maybe others have more open space available. The alternative is of course for the player to build a giant platform in the sky suspended on pillars to be their artificial flat factory floor. For me that option has proven a bit too silly to actually implement.

At the 40 hour mark, this game became so mind numbingly tedious that it became unenjoyable. I hope you enjoy spending literal days trying to unlock the rest of the gameplay with the world's most boring and painful grind because thats what you're going to get.

It took 5 full days of play just to unlock tiers 5 and 6. Now we have to make 4x the amount of stuff with about 10x the work to get to Tiers 7 and 8. We've barely made a dent in it, its been 3 days. It used to be easier, but they made it harder to pad the gameplay because it's an EA title.

Which was absolutely unnecessary, this game can be really fun on its own without excessive amounts of grind.

Also, have fun trying to make the stuff you need when the game glitches out and machines won't work or you can't build. That's going to make the grind even harder.

Buy it on sale.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
If you've been considering this game, you should absolutely give it a try, and you'll probably get hooked just like I did.

Satisfactory is an amazing game. Not just in the factory building aspect, but also in many other ways.

Obviously, this game is about making a factory. And that it does excellently - goals are clear, it's easy to pick up and keeps you engaged, it's extremely satisfying and it makes your brain work. I know there have been many times where I've built a brand new production line and just stared at it for 10 or 15 mins watching the materials move through the conveyors I just built. It's so satisfying. There's always something new to do or discover, and each tier brings exciting new machines and materials to play with. The progression is excellent too, with the game guiding you to where you need to go but also giving you the freedom to build the biggest factory you want at any point. There are so many dimensions and so many things you can produce in so many different ways - it gives you a framework and then you're free to do whatever.

The graphics are really nice and everything is super detailed. The animations in this game are AWESOME - even early on you start to get multiple favourite animations that you just watch over and over again.

Even though it's a building game, it's also one of exploration. And surprisingly, that it does really well too. The combat, once you get a past the xeno zapper (which happens pretty quickly) is fun, engaging, and satisfying. The alien enemies are well done - I also loved Subnautica, and some of them got me almost as scared as being chased by a reaper leviathan. The enemy design is also really unique - I absolutely didn't expect these going into the game. Apparently there's a story coming by 1.0, too, and it's already written - I'd love that, there's so much potential for a great narrative for this game.

The exploration is great, with the environments being far away but not too far, and each is very unique and very beautiful. All the biomes are different to each other and exploring through them for the first time is really fun and interesting.

Overall, almost every aspect of this game is great and I can barely think of flaws. There's a few bugs here and there, quality of life things, etc, but the graphics are great, the gameplay loop is great, the factory building aspect is well thought out and very fun, and the world in which the game is set is beautiful and interesting.

All this praise, and this game is still early access. Coffee Stain has done an amazing job so far, and I'm sure they'll continue to deliver with Satisfactory.

Single player review.
This game is an absolute blessing to play.

The first 30 mins of the game is a bit hard to get into. I feel like there's improvement to be made there.
Personally I think holding the hand of the player for that duration would be helpful. It would help not feeling like you've never done this before.

I don't do many reviews, but boy is this game is just excellent! I had been in kind of a gaming funk - nothing really kept my interest for very long. This game really changed all that. The balance of grind to exploration to combat is great and I'm happy there aren't typical "survival" mechanics that tend to just be annoying later stage in these types of games.

I was skeptical that this would just be a "real-life lite" simulator, but setting up factories and supply chains is surprisingly fun and intuitive right out the gate and incredibly rewarding to master.

I could go on for a while, but suffice it to say: If you're at all into build-it games, this is a must have!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I will attempt to be clear in brief: It is not worth it's price. Plain and simple. It is a fun game, it is a game that had me play it for 8 straight hours, but I got it on sale and imagined it to be a cleaner looking Factorio. But it isn't, at least not yet. If I may recommend such a game, it's Dyson Sphere Program.

Issues and Solutions
It severely lacks the (what I find to be a very simple yet effective system) basic research system. Using basic mats to create basic research tokens and scaling that. Instead it desires the player to create more and more nonsense from basic resources. I generally dislike it but that may be a person gripe. What however I believe are the two most disruptive parts of this game are as follows: 1. The exploration and 2. The M.A.M. research aside from the Space Elevator research. The exploration is great, for the first time. But the world is not procedural, it is a created map, good for introducing players and very poor for keeping players engaged when they must inhabit the same map constantly. The MAM research, and specifically the alternative research paths are absolutely awful. They don't inspire me to create new factories, they push me to tear down my construction of which I already spent so long optimizing to do it all over again, that is not the game play loop I enjoy. If they were given immediately I wouldn't have issue, they'd allow the player to experiment to find which recipe actually created the best result, instead of handing me a new recipe which is simply a direct upgrade to my current system but is incompatible with it. But nonetheless; I have what I believe to be a very perfect analogy for this game. This is No Man's Sky with automation, and without ships. Now hear me out Devs, what if...what if you put those together, and make a small solar system that can use the existing maps and allows players to still chose starting locations but has very different experiences for the different locations allowing varied play styles on each planet and in the 'end game' you then travel to the different planets and start colonies to feed your mecha world? It sounds like a fun game to me, and would add a lot of depth.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I hit the 40 years of age mark, and I've thought a lot about how games used to be more immersive and enjoyable in my younger years.

It's not unusual for me to try a highly praised game and get bored after an hour or two.

Bought this, tried it out. The first night I stayed up to 6am and went to bed only so my girlfriend wouldn't realize how long I had stayed up. I dreamt of factories.

Then the next day I pretty much ignored her and continued to optimize and build factories.

Then I stayed up and continued playing until 6am again.

At some point I'll install the game again and lie to her about working long hours, but until then all I have to say is that it got more out of me in a week than almost any other game has in years.

For the cost to entertainment factor it's already passed it, and it's early access. Crazy.

This is easily my favorite game. Very addicting game play loop.

There's no real pressure when it comes to the survival aspect, you won't starve, you can stand still for 3 hours and not die, but don't let this fool you. You will feel the drive to strive ahead and build ever more complex systems to harvest the resources of the planet you're on and when any piece of that puzzle falls into place, the feeling can only really be described as Satisfactory.

10/10 Highly recommend this game to just about anyone.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS GAME! It's sad that it's so under rated. I've got 87 hrs played as of writing this review, and that's just on Steam, not to mention my ungodly amount of time in the first platform it was released on. The amount of time you can spend just gathering resources at first, then tear it down and get more organized, get faster, get upgrades, and so much more!

Not to mention all the exploring you get to do in a very well made world with fona and flora. It's so easy to sink in this game and get lost and just enjoy every aspect of it.

For those that rate this game as NOT good, I tend to see you only have less than 10 hours played. You really need to get much further and more time into it to really give this a fair review, otherwise, I personally don't consider reviews with less than 10 hours played to be honest. There's too many reviews that also bicker and whine about the gameplay which is super minor compared to what does work and is usable.

I personally give this game a 9.6 of 10 due to those minor glitches. However, this game has a long way to go yet and I can't wait to see what comes out next with it.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I am so ridiculously hooked on this game. It is the dopamine fix that my ADHD-addled brain has craved for years but until now, never could sate.

They didn't have to go so hard on making the graphics this beautiful, but they did. They didn't have to make the sound design so completely perfect, but treat your ears to the sound of belts setting. They didn't have to encourage rebuilding and rethinking your factory layouts by refunding all materials in deconstruction, but clearly, the devs want us to enjoy every part of the game without punishing us for learning or wanting to improve efficiency and aesthetic.

I cannot wait to see what else is coming as we continue through the Early Access phase. Well worth the money, I cannot recommend it enough!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
That moment when you wonder why your steel production is so low and then realize your primary foundry has no power because you went to wall mounts from power poles and forgot to connect said foundry.

Problems like this are why I love the game. Figuring out how to get the most efficiency out of your setup, get max production running, so on and so forth. I love a game that forces me to think instead of mindless blasting. Although don't get me wrong, sometimes we all need to do a little mindless blasting to blow off some steam. This game is that, but it's relaxing, fun and well worth your $30.

Don't worry if you're first base (such as what I'm working on now) has a belt system that looks like spaghetti, you can always rebuild and improve. Do buy this game if you're into building sims and such. It's a great way to relax after a hard work day.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's pretty staggering looking back at your humongous, continent-spanning factory, and thinking about how when you started you were just stabbing at some iron ore with a knife.

It's the sort of game where you've always got 5 tasks you want to complete, and every completed task makes you realize there are 2 more things you need to do. You can stop any time you want, but natural stopping points are rare, and thus this game can eat up the hours like few can. If you're the sort to spend all night playing Rimworld, this game will consume you.

Beware that in addition to the GPU, this game is very intensive on your CPU, especially as your factory grows. I had to abandon the game for a while because my old computer was CPU-bottlenecked.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Great, really great impression by early access game. The maps are large and populated. Easily unerstandable gameplay, decent UI nad UX (for early access). Open world with seamlessly integrated story and discover surpizes. By the time of review the game is in state when its gameplay quite good balanced between calm and adventurous. Grinding-like gameplay is a part of fun in these games.

Good quality of world design, although it lacks some randomality when i restart the sesstion. Thus Satisfactory could benefit from implementation of balanced semi-random resource allocation and repopulating of the world at start. Looking for resources and optimal placement each time would add more replayability. Additionaly Satisfactory would benefit from dinamically changing gameplay (which might be an switchable option for those who like more challenging gameplay) and ecosystem simulation (selflearning AI adaptig the difficulty to the style of playing, which might be an switchable option also; something Rimworld-like maybe).

The game runs in 64bit address space without a lags at low settings (looking great nevertheless) on my 16GB RAM laptop, with integrated GPU of i7 CPU.

Definitely recommend.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This is a very Satisfying game, pun intended. Lots 'o' content to unlock, and a decent yet not frustrating challenge to be found in unlocking it. I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys engineering style problems and building infrastructure. I personally really enjoy the process of setting everything up and later on fine-tuning my setup to get a greater efficiency. Also, the fact that there will be more content in the future is really exciting, since I've only just unlocked nearly all of the available content in my first playthrough. Pretty sure the replay value is high on this one :)
Although there are plenty of glitches still, most of them aren't annoying. In fact, most of the glitchy things I've seen are either harmless visual glitches or ones that actually increase your freedom to build in different ways within the game! Even better, the developers acknowledge this and agree to keep those glitches which increase the enjoyability of the game.
All things said, I'd rate this game 10/10 and I look forward to the new content when it comes, as well as any lore that may be added to flesh out the game's more ominous bits and pieces (currently WIP)

This game is absolutely amazing! I honestly don't know where to even begin! The opening sequence had me so excited - the planet fall, the music, and the doors opening to the epic landscape filled with potential, was just beautiful. The concept of the game and the futuristic feel is so well accomplished. The UI is masterly crafted and so intuitive. The game just looks downright gorgeous. EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I recently described this game as an endeavor which some might find boring, while others find it completely awesome.
I'm very much in the latter camp.
I love building and production oriented games, so for me, this game has proven to be fantastic.
I can understand how others may not enjoy it's crafting and production focused sandbox, with limited exploration and alien killing, but for those of us who enjoy setting up networks of distribution and construction, those of us with some level of OCD where we really need to have those conveyors and pipelines lined up correctly, those of us who must continue to achieve the next level of technology to progress into a whole new set of challenges, this game is quite excellent.
I even enjoyed the time I spent taking down the nuclear production network since it was creating so very much waste and danger in parts of my map. Who knew that the process of getting rid of something I built would be fun, too?
Anyhow - strong recommendation for the crafty ones of us.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Another great experience from Coffee Stain.

Only grab this game if you have the time, curiosity, and patience to really invest in this genera! This game is a steal at the sale price and a huge sleeper for 2021.

-The world is massive, beautiful, dangerous, and beckons you to explore it.
-The mechanics are beautifully polished and feed into each other in a very well thought out progression.
-Progression feels rewarding and scales well with each advancement.
-The game runs great and though it is an "early access" title at the time of this review, I have yet to experience any crashes or major bugs.
-There is subtle humor tucked into all the interactions you have with the company you work for.

Do yourself a favor and check it out, it's Overwhelmingly Positive for a reason.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
At almost 60 hours of playtime, I've thoroughly enjoyed my time playing Satisfactory so far! In early access, even at this stage in the game it is highly playable. I haven't played Factorio but others have called this a 3D version of that game.

A lot of this game reminds me of the joys of playing Minecraft around the time it was first acquired by Microsoft. Back then, we played it on Xbox 360 and before creative mode was introduced. Like Minecraft, this game is one where you kind of have to create your own fun, in some ways.

There's isn't much of a story - you're mostly just a worker who's been tasked with mining resources and sending products out to your space homies. You have loose objectives - "build this stuff, and then you'll be able to build this other stuff that will unlock". Everything builds off of each other, so there's a natural progression of unlocking new components as you advance through the game to build new materials that lets you build other things.

The fun you have in this game is what you make of it, just like in Minecraft. It's a sandbox game with loose objectives and you're constantly building bigger and more efficient assembly lines to produce goods better and faster. You'll probably find that you spend an hour or so building an assembly line and then ten hours later you tear it all down and rebuild it even more efficiently than you did before, and it's never frustrating! You don't think "meh, but that's an hour of my life I won't get back!" You just do it and enjoy the puzzle-solving aspects of it all. And that's really what this game is... it's an open-ended puzzle game where you're finding creative solutions to get to the next objective, and the objective is what you choose it to be.

This is a really fun game. It's challenging. It's thought-provoking. It's got a ton of number-crunching behind the scenes that you can completely ignore or dive head-first into to build a better assembly. I do wish that the game had procedural generation, but that's only a minor inconvenience, and I only suggest it because there are a ton of resources for "go here and build your base here at this spot for the best resources" and it takes some of the fun and excitement out of the game. All in all though, if you enjoy games that feature resource management, exploration, solving creative processes, base building, light combat, and freedom to play when and how you want to, then give Satisfactory a shot!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Honestly, one of the most addicting games that I've ever had the privilege of playing. There are quite a few pros and cons I'd like to lay out about this game. Firstly though, I'd like to note that this game is well worth the asking price, even unfinished.

Pros:
The hand crafted world is really beautiful and the ambiance draws you in completely. The animals in the world make it feel alive, and even though they are annoying sometimes, they add a new level of immersion to the game.
The game itself is beautiful, and the options to make a more naturalistic type factory or an enclosed warehouse are both there, making two, and possibly more play styles to enjoy.
On top of that, the vehicles and the fun factor in this game are really high... If you're sick of making stuff, just make a race course or skate park to play in with your friends.

Cons:
There are a lot of cons, and that's to be expected, in no way did they make me want to return the game, however.
Firstly, there is no way to equip multiple items to the body, it would make sense for some items to work together, i.e. the gas mask and the blade runner.... As these don't conflict with each other whatsoever. It would also add a whole new level of mobility as you got to higher levels. Having to switch out the jetpack and the bladerunner sometimes seems unnecessary.
There is no real functional way of snapping and locking the place of buildings in order to make them properly aligned. If you are a bit pickier about this, it might drive you crazy. You'll constantly find yourself placing buildings in the wrong spot and having to redo their placement.
I expect in a future update they will add more cosmetic furniture so you can make your own little home away from factory, so to speak, or the ability to lounge on the couch while you watch your glorious production lines from the window above.
Animal husbandry still seems like it's in its infancy, but I look forward to future updates to see what happens to that. :)

As I said, this game is amazing and the price tag justifies the content, heck, it's worth more money than I think its going for. It's still early access though, so there's a few rough patches to work out. Hope you enjoy this game as much as I do.
