It is still an early access game, therefore not free from bugs and lack of fundamental functions, but it is not a problem. Nothing that could spoil the gameplay too much
For example, trains, like many structures, do not have collisions. So you can go through them and build through them.
Also, there is not yet a system to release fluid such as water, you need to flow the pipes or the buffers manually. This can easy "fix" by edit the water pump and add an option to drain water instead of extract.





Is 30 € well spent? Yes.
Would I play it for many hours? If you're into that genre, you'll make it a lot of hours.
The game is updated in steps of months, perhaps a bit slow and the developers have the habit of taking days off for every single holiday, extending the development a lot, but in the end it is updated and I think it will be for a long time.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
So I've been playing Satisfactory for a week or so with my kids, sinking a decent amount of time into learning the game and how it works. Consider this an initial review.

The exploration side is really impressive for an early access game. The world is handcrafted and quite beautiful in places, and great fun to explore. The vehicles are fun to drive around in so far (I've only unlocked up to the truck so far - more on why later). The sound fits the ambience really well, and the graphics are smooth and clean. There are a few glitches to be found, like getting stuck in trees when you try to climb them, and the draw distance creates some really jarring pop-ins at times. I'm hopeful these will get fixed with time.

The factory/building side definitely scratches my optimisation itch, and while I'll try not to compare it to Factorio it does fill the '3D Factorio' void that I never knew I was missing. Placing production lines and tinkering with over/underclocking machines so that everything is perfectly balanced feels great and would make Thanos proud. Getting your first small factory perfectly set up and running optimally is a great feeling!

So would I recommend it? Well, no, not at this stage.

The first tiers of research can be completed more or less with just your starting HUB and a local factory. As you go up the research tiers each new item requires more production of the previous tier items, in a natural progression. Steel is where I first started to really scale up production and subsequently factory sizes, and ran into the brick wall that is factory building in Satisfactory. Everything must be placed individually. Everything. Every time.

If you're like me and you've designed a modular factory from the start, so you can just scale it easily to increase production? Nope. Every foundation, every machine, every belt and every splitter/merger/power line must be placed, one at a time, by hand. Every machine must have its recipe set individually. I'm looking at hundreds of machines, and thousands of items in total, all to be placed by hand - and I'm only in the mid-game! And heaven forfend you unlock an alternate, more efficient recipe, because then you need to tear down and redesign the factory all over again.

There are no blueprint or copy/paste planners in the game, and the Devs have said repeatedly that they won't be implementing them either, as they want every item to be hand-placed. That's fine, it is their game after all, but I definitely don't agree. There are mods available as workarounds, but I find them unreliable to use (more practice may change that).

To clarify the above, I'm not looking for a creative mode to fix this problem, though that would be nice to have regardless. What I would like is to be able to hand place a factory module, laid out perfectly, and then select it (including all of the power lines, belts, foundations as well) and build it again if I have the resources in my inventory. Exactly the same build process as now, only I'm building more than one item at a time. That's all.

So to sum up - I enjoy playing the early game, and exploring the world with my kids. But if you enjoy building large-scale factories that are efficient, and you don't have days to spend each time you need to change something, I would not recommend the game at this point.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I MUST BE EFFICIENT
Satisfactory is a brilliant Early Access game by Coffee Stain Studios. The objective is to build a factory on an alien planet and make it as efficient as possible. The game ropes you in with a fairly straight forward tutorial and keeps things easy at the start, getting progressively more micro-managing and new as you continue to reach milestones and objectives. I did think to myself "Why would I want to have a game where I just make a factory and create resources?", but before I knew it, I was playing the game consistently for a while because it had me hooked. You manage power, train lines, drones, conveyor belts, it never seems to end. It has a calm feel to it, enemies don't come and ruin your factory, they just lurk about in the exploration areas and you can create weapons to defend yourself against them when you are adventuring across the huge map that is available to you. There's many different ways to build, its entirely up to you as long as you have the resources. The community behind the game is great and seeing other peoples builds gives you inspiration and it pushes creativity out of everyone. I rate Coffee Stain Studios very well for their developer updates and community interaction and can confidently say that this game is worth buying at full price even with the Early Access title attached to it. On top of all this, the game looks graphically pleasing and finds the gap where it isn't too demanding but looks good. I've played a few times with friends too and it helps to get the factories off the floor when you start a new world. The game is a gem and should be in all Steam libraries.

With my current factory, I'm near an end game point, and it's definitely dragging due to the fact I have less to focus on. The new update does help end game factories and builders by giving that new content itch, but it could do with some more to it when you're at that point. Apart from that, the game is a no brainer.

Played for an hour or 2 so far and this is a great game. Theres not too much of a learning curve and everything is kept fairly simple while still keeping you wanting more. There are very few bugs considering the fact it's still in development. The only bug i've come across is the conveyer belts wanting to place into the ground, blocking whatever is on the conveyerbelt.

You don't need to spend forever gathering material and the crafting menu makes it very easy to make what you need. The building part of the game is just as simple and doesn't try to be overly complicated. I do wish that I had started in a more open area as the game suggested because my system is very congested.

I like the odd aliens that wander about, especially the giant potato with legs. Overall, I would highly suggest this game for the hardcore or passive gamer as it has a lot to offer and doesn't require a PhD to remember things if you drop off for a week or 4.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
So, so, so, Satisfactory. Where do I begin? And where do I end? Much like a new players first attempt at a factory which lead to spaghetti, let's start at the beginning. Yknow. As any place should, I suppose!

I first learned of Satisfactory when I'd been followin' coffee stain on twitter. Big fan of sanctum and all that. Got sad it was an EGS thing, waited for it to hit steam and so it did. Bought it when I found out. So, how do I feel about it?

All in all, I think it's quite good. The music feels chill, I absolutely adore the designs in this game. They've crafted such a pretty world that is rather quite large, too. And packed it full of things to find or just nice places ot look at. And the designs of the buildings and vehicles and just.. stuff like that? It's all boxy, orange,I love it. It's great.

The actual main part, the building + factory stuff, is.. about what you'd expect I suppose! You get introduced to the basics, figure out how some things work, and things get more complicated. You find, handcraft, automate, unlock, and kinda repeat, and so it goes. Though, I think Satisfactory is a bit more easy to.. grasp? So long as you're willing to do some maths. Yknow, stuff like "Oh hey, this uses 15. I make 30 currently. I have 120 of this, so 120 divided by 30" and so on.

You can make some spaghetti with your conveyors or power lines but.. the game don't mind too much. Things like conveyors and pipes can clip through eachother most of the time and.. Yknow hwat? I'm okay with that. There are other factory games (which I shall not mention for many reasons) which don't let me do that. And sometimes it hurts my brain when I can't. We aren't all experts, and some of us don't wanna watch a 3 hour long video guide on how to set up the most efficient factory and take out the fun of figuring it out. I appreciate that I can break physics every now and then.

Anyway, that's the building part. So how about the rest?
It goes simple enough. You got your irons, your iron products, your copper and copper products early game, iron becomes more complicated when you need 3 things to make 3 other things that require 2 of the before mentioned thing, yknow. Stuff like that.

Then you get your coals and your irons and your steels, and your slowly but surely increasingly complicated products from it.
Other liquids get added, and byproducts from those liquids you need to plan for andadd into your increasingly complicated layouts, all that stuff. Mind, I don't think the early/mid game is that hard to work your brain around? It's when you get oils and long ra nge transport things get.. weird, to me at least.

(addendum: I forgot to add this, but to make a quick edit: Exploration is rewarded with a lot, but keep a keen eye. You find Freighters dotted about the place. Fix them up, get their harddives. Scan them at the M.A.M. and you'll be rewarded with some alt-recipes. Some of these are amazing and game changers. Love; a confused lizard)

Another thing I think benefits this, I get the feeling the people making the map were actually kinda smart. I've found several locations that are just wonderfully perfect for certain things. Find a nice lil place to make steel in the rocky desert. I got something that needs steel pipes and copper, and then I got hit by it
"Oh, ♥♥♥♥! RIGHT, MY STEEL PLACE HAS COPPER NEXT TO IT."

I feel this game is kinda slow a lot of the time. There's a lot of periods where.. nothing is really going on? You're just kinda waiting for your machines to do the heavy lifting before you unlock the new stuff. Use those down times to explore your surroundings. Figure out where you'll source new materials, pathways to take, find slugs, find delicious carapace or organs, get terrified by the local fauna when you realise there's creepy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ spiders that spit acidic spikes at you
(or, in my case, pictures of floating cat faces that drool green slime because I have arachnophobia mode on. Yes, there is "I'm scared of spiders" mode that replaces them with floating cat faces. And the cats meow, instead of make the horrid skittering sound those Stingers make.)

The game gives you some movement options relatively early on if you can find them. Here's some advice, if you want it:

Oh, I forgot to mention. So you can "Overclock" things in this game. You unlock it early on, and they very much want you to use it. It lets you simplify, or complicate, your designs. You can find these slugs all over the place, I call them "Friends", and you can use them to make power shards. Plug power shards into something, and it starts working faster. Something like a screw constructor uses 10 iron rods, and a single iron rod constructor makes 15. Soo.. rather than building 2 of those and building 3 of the others, you could just make 1, overlock the other to 150% and make things less of a headache.
EDIT: I learnt that Overclocking drastically increases power usage of a building. So much so that a single refinery will use about 150 MW at 250% overclock. So careful with that! underclocking has the opposite effect. In terms of energy use, underclocking buildings uses a lot less power but requires you to use more space when building.

I think the only thing I /don't/ like about this game is the early game power. It's all handcrafted or hand found. I don't really enjoy running around, picking up leaves and wood, turning it into biomass, into solid biofuel, dumping it into biofuel burners and then getting to work and praying I work fast enough to "out-run" the situation where i run out of fuel and I have to spend another age cutting down trees and foliage to power the generators.

The moment you unlock coal and coal burners, this problem goes away. So my advice? Get Coal Power ASAP.

I love the movement options in this game. Anywhere from "ride on my power line" to "Jump pads, baby!" to "I'm going to make this tube so long I will afk for 5 minutes as I get flung towards my oil by a transparent tube."
Unfortunately, I can't tell you what I think of mid/late game, because I never made it that far. I always end up feeling terrible that I can't build right, or i just don't have the energy to figure it out. But just because I get sad about it, doesn't mean you shouldn't check Satisfactory out if it catches your fancy.

Just remember, if you're struggling to figure it out.. just take a step back. Take a few breaths, and just go "Alright, let me break this down in my head."

And remember, if you need space, platforms are your friend. No room? Build up. FICSIT encourages verticality to streamline short range transportation. But they also defy physics, and if you want you could just make a floating sky factory on platforms.


... Okay, one more thing. The space elevator is one of the coolest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ things ever. I never get tired of seeing that animation. Or watching my constructors work.. or listening to the sound of machinery chug and hum. It's great.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I'm a 1000 hours in, and still playing.

If you like base building, balancing production lines, and minor scrapes of combat to mix things up, then this is a good game to lose track of time playing.

Beautiful hand placed world, plenty of exploration the first few go arounds and I'm still discovering things I haven't seen before here and there.

Combat is limited, not a focal point to the game at all, but still something to get the heart racing at times.

Very chill, there's never a running clock, get done what you do when you do. Milestones along the way reward you for progress with new recipes/gear/buildings etc.

Multiplayer is a bit wonky, only real drawback atm. It isn't as plug and play as the rest of the game but it's getting better and some have more luck with it than others.

So if you like the way that sounds, snag the game.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Update after 126 h:

One of the best games I've played in many years, it's the only game which returns the game experience of the ancient Transport Tycoon (TTD) game from the 90s. The setting up of conveyor belts and controlling input-output is pretty much like the railway construction in that old classic but in 3D, plus you unlock trains in midgame. Because of this the game has as much replay value as it too because you can always find new ways to accomplish what you want.

TTD didn't have any objectives and still was fun and so is Satisfactory, although there is no money in Satisfactory but TTD didn't have a tier progression system.

Game is good as it is, anything extra is a bonus in terms of new updates. The fun factor increases the more you progress in the game compared to many games that stagnate midgame, if you find the beginning to be fun then expect it to be uberfun later on. If you find the very beginning to be dull with manual harvest for fueling biomass generators please be patient and unlock coal power as soon as possible as then electricity generation becomes automated then and you almost don't have to do much manual labor anymore other than building structures and crafting some handheld equipment.

There is at least one annoying bug but it isn't game breaking except that I lost an Explorer vehicle that went underground more than once (which I recovered via some 3rd party tool). Some building blocks have issues to snap in place properly such as the walkway ramps. The AI drivers which follow recorded routes can be a bit crazy, don't stand in their way because they don't care if you or your vehicle are there and they tend to get stuck if you don't plan their routes very carefully (which may lead to them going out of fuel somewhere so you need to go on a rescue mission).

Original review:

The game is interesting for players who would like a focus on the engineering part of construction games, because you build your own industry on an alien planet and are responsible for resource gathering (via automatic miners very early), electricity production and managing various kinds of machines like constructors and assemblers to manufacture components which can be used to place new structures or finish progression tiers.

You start off with quite a bit of micromanagement which can become automated eventually as you progress, and it can be annoying to fill machines like biofuel manually, but as you progress machines can handle it and it's not too much of a nuisance. Micromanagement will always involve setting up and changing production queues and making sure you have enough juice so a fuse won't blow.

The game lacks a real purpose for your industry, like an economy, which other reviews have also highlighted and is something the developer could work on, however I understand it's an alpha game so I'm not loudly criticizing them. But the tier system of progression keeps you occupied for hours and it's unfair to whine too much about it.

The challenge of the game is to make your industry more efficient like prevent machines from causing delays to other machines, maximize the output, and so you don't have to do things by hand, for example move things manually between machines, which can be a challenge. A lot of the stuff can be automated if you set it up properly.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's great if you like pretending to be an engineer, mechanic, explorer, etc. I bought the game for $23.99 and I believe it's worth it. I have been having a blast the first 10+ hours, and can't wait to play some more tomorrow. Very polished for early access, I became glued to the floor once in the 10+ hours I played and just loaded a recent auto-save to undo it. The only other down side I hope they improve upon is that the game only has one hand made map, which limits replay-ability. The game is unfinished but I am still putting in many hours. I am running out of new things to do, so hopefully they add some more content soon. As I have been playing, I have noticed many clipping issues with getting stuck on certain aspects of the terrain, and I have to load an auto-save most times to fix it, I lose a little bit of time when it happens, but it doesn't happen all the time, but it is annoying when it does happen. The auto-save is similar to Valheim, in it causes you to lag briefly when flying with the jetpack, and has caused me to get injured a few times. I have found items that do not have a use yet, but I am hanging onto them for now. There are also items I find (sprites I guess) that are hovering/floating in the air, which ruins some of the immersion. That's all I can say for now. I do not particularly like using the scroll wheel to cycle through my gear in my belt, it takes too long and does not seem to follow a predictable order and when you need a certain weapon or other item quickly, it is not reliable at all, there should be a hot bar or quickbar for you weapons like you have for building parts etc.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I played this game but I had to get a refund. The main reasons were: (1) I need a zoomable camera where I can look down upon buildings, etc. - I never did like first-person on any of my games; (2) I prefer the snap-to-grid style rather than free placement, only for stylistic reasons and my OCD; (3) I know it is in 'early access' phase right now, so many upgrades are coming, but since I am not sure what that will look like, I decided to play it safe and come back to this title at another date (for another sale).

It seems to be a really good game, primarily graphically for its genre. For this game, I think that XBOX Controller support would be awesome. I will keep an eye out for the 'Creative Mode' they are talking about. Also, I am interested in this game due to the great communication of the developer - that's what made me take the plunge in the first place. I am sure I will be back to buy Satisfactory.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A very good first-person version of automation/supply chain games like Factorio, Dyson Sphere Program, etc. The world feels fleshed out with lots of different creatures and diverse environments to explore. The FICSIT aesthetic and design is very sleek, what you would expect from a futuristic company. I also love the sound design in the game! There are a number of sounds, like pinging the location of nearby resources, that are extremely satisfying to hear.

Remember, the game is still in Early Access and you will find bugs or limits to the game's content. There are a handful of resources with the WIP (Work in Progress) label and the multiplayer experience leaves something to be desired.

If you're looking for a fairly fleshed out Early Access game in the style of Factorio, I would highly recommend this game.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Primero que nada el juego esta bien optimizado. Las animaciones de las maquinas y herramientas son muy buenas y desde el momento en que inicie con mis primeras herramientas me atrapo en el apartado grafico.
La curva de nivel es muy buena: Comienzas con un crafteo a mano muy basico para despues pasar a un crafteo automatizado, que es de lo que va el juego. La complejidad de los materiales que debes de craftear va aumentando poco a poco y el proceso comienza a ser mas largo y aunque esto puede sonar tedioso en realidad es lo divertido del juego.

SE EFICIENTE, es el lema del juego y conforme el juego avanza vas a querer generar lineas de trabajo mucho mas eficientes para cumplir tus objetivos.

This game is pretty great. I found it first when watching Let's Game It Out, but there's much more you can do with this game than what he shows you in his videos. You'll definitely start off with a more sloppy factory, but once you get the hang of the game, you can make a better one somewhere else on the map. EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Incredibly fun and I've had many amazing moments so far. I've gotten to T6 so my feedback will be from that experience.

Visuals - 9/10
Audio - 9/10
Mechanics - 7/10
Gameplay elements: 5/10

WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD

Feedback on mechanics and gameplay elements:

+ Building with conveyors and lifts is incredibly fun. You can make some really wacky factories and setups.

+ Removing and adding structures is fast and versatile. Well done on that end.

- There's only one "body" slot. You can't wear more than one of for example blade runners, jetpack nor the gas mask. Switching between these is incredibly annoying and frequently disrupts the gameplay.

- Machines cannot tilt one bit. Building in slopes is awkward.

- It's not feasible to elevate machines/foundations to a desired height without an anchor point from somewhere else and even with that, they'll either be floating in the air or standing on foundations from the ground.

- It'd be great if you could swap the input/outputs for machines which have both fluids and items, like the refinery. It's more or less a symmetry/design thing and irrelevant for mechanics.

- Alternative recipes often don't make sense. For example, Caterium Ingots can give Copper Wire, they are two different materials and it makes no sense. It's great that core resources can be produced in much higher quantities later on. Maybe there could be dynamic recipes instead.

- Conveyor belts require no power and seemingly run from nothing. Some nodes can be kilometers from your main base and transporting these via conveyor belts is taxing on game performance. Trains is an option but they're incredibly power consuming, especially when you need them around T5-6.

- There's a lack of variety for arsenal. I would love to see something like a bow or crossbow.

- More often than not you'll encounter the same enemies, i.e fire/acid spitting dinosaurs, charging dinosaurs, the airborne stingers and/or spiders and they all exist in every biome.

- There's only 4 types of healing items, deez nuts, bacon things, berries and the medical item.

----------------------------------------

It's a fantastic game though. I can see why my friends recommended it to me.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Greetings.

I would very much recommend this game for anyone who loves factory-type games and exploration, and doesn't mind some very minor combat. (Also, you should probably make sure your computer can run it.)

When I first got this game, I was playing on a computer with integrated radeon graphics (if you are not a nerd, basically I was playing on a potato). I had about 6 fps on ultra low settings, but I still enjoyed it. More on that later. After a couple months on that, I switched to a computer with a Ryzen 7 4000H Processor and a GTX 1650 ti with 16 gb of ram. With those specs, I am currently able to run a decently sized factory at 60 fps on Ultra Settings. This has made the game much more enjoyable, but I never hated it even when it was running at 6 fps. This is because I love the core gameplay elements this has to offer. My favorite part is going from nothing to hand-crafting to a small unorganized factory to a better and bigger factory to many factories around the world to a whole network of factories working together just to make over 50 turbo-motors per minute.

Here's how it works: You select a place (I would suggest the green hills just because it is very easy to start in). Then, you find your first node (usually of iron). Then, you start hand-picking at that thing until you can create a way to do that automatically. But, iron ore isn't very useful. You need to craft it into something, so now you are sitting at the crafting bench, waiting for your iron to be made into something else when you say, "I should really automate this." And after that, once you set up a production chain, you can go explore, and when you come back, you will have bins full of materials. You then just keep going. It never really gets boring. You can either make super efficient factories capable of making a TON of items per minute, or you can make a less efficient factory that works okay, but wastes a lot of time and materials. But it is really up to you, and how you choose to play.

Power is also fun. When you start out, you are having to feed these biomass burners with leaves and sticks in order to keep power, but then, you unlock coal power, fuel power, geothermal power, and then (spoiler) ! And that last one is complicated to say the least, but by that point, you'll be ready for it.

The map is huge. Though it is finite, it never feels like it. Yes, I have seen the edge of the map, but it is nothing to be concerned about. You will never run out of room to build a base.

There is some mild combat to the game, but it's nothing much. If you go exploring and you are un-equiped for the area, then it might be a challenge. But throughout the game, you will be able to upgrade your weapons to make it even easier.

Mods! Unfortunately, there is no built-in support for Mods in Steam, but they are possible, you just need to download Satisfactory Mods Manager via their website online, so once you do that, it's not a very big deal. There are three types of mods in my opinion: one, the game-breaking types that some might like, but I don't. Two: The types that are game-breaking if you abuse them, but can be helpful if you just don't want to take time going to your storage room. Lastly, there is the third type which are useful mods that just make life easier. With the right combination, mods can either make a playthrough more enjoyable, or just mix things up if you are playing again.

I, myself, have not quite finished one playthrough, but I'm close. And when I do, I'll just start over and instead take a different approach in automating every item in the game. I don't think I'll be bored for a while at least.

So, again, I highly recommend this game if you like factory-type games and exploring. Again, the combat is not too bad, and the game is very optimized . But apart from that, just a couple of tips for you if you do decide to buy this:

1) Just build a storage room, guys. It makes it all easier.
2) The second you unlock Hypertubes, USE THEM, and put them all around your base.
3) Overclock as many miners as possible. You can build infinite machines, but there are limited resource nodes.
4) Just because a line's materials isn't moving doesn't mean you can just split that line and take whatever you need; that might be supporting a production chain that is just not currently in use and all backed up.
5) Don't forget about research! It is useful.
6) Build a starting factory that is messy, then, leave your computer running for a couple of hours. Then, come back, and then use those resources that were just generated to build your new, permanent factory.
7) Trains are cool, but too many of them start to lag, so be careful. (I am unsure about drones)
8)

9)

Thank you for reading my honest review, and I hope you have a great day.

- How are the graphics and how does the game run? The graphics are amazing, the game runs very smooth. It is in early access but the Devs are working very hard, it runs much better than what they say, which is good news for us, that means its going to be as close to perfect as they can.

- Are the Devs actively working on the game I see it has been in early access a while? They are the most interactive development studio I have had dealings with, you should tune in on Tuesday to watch the dev stream on Twitch. Jayce is quitting real soon but someone will be there.

- Would you recommend this game? All joking aside from earlier in my review, totally, this is a game that will give you hours and hours of fun. I have bought this for several friends and strangers, this game is so good it draws you in, you will want to share it with everyone.

- I read in reviews multiplayer is broken, is this true? No, this is an absolute untruth. Multiplayer works very well, and far better than the Devs give themselves credit for. The problem with multiplayer that you have read about in other reviews, is in the chair of the reviewer. Enjoy multiplayer as well, Play this game how you like.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Yeah. Buy this game. Phenomenal. <3

Things I'd love to see later on if any of the devs read these reviews!

1. A scanner that can be used to scan creatures/objects/items, provide little tidbits of info when you scan them, and have a progression system for it, the more stuff you scan, the more little rewards you can get, that kinda thing, like in No Man's Sky, I LOVE that system and I feel like this small thing would benefit this game a lot.

2. More weapons, I'm sure there will be more, as this is still considered early access..but I'm just saying~

3. No map limits, if we can see it, we should be able to go there. I don't like seeing the edge of the world, makes the map feel a little small. >.<

4. A more active enemy system, options to build turrets for base defense, spikes, bigger walls, gates, that kinda stuff. Having my base in the middle of a field with no threats to it on an alien planet definitely doesn't feel right, in my honest opinion. I know the game is more centered on building, and people may like having a peaceful environment, but adding difficulty options at least, like peaceful/hostile environments would awesome, kindof like how the Valheim enemy system works. :)

5. A radio that we can load songs into somehow so we can listen to some tunes as we build and explore!

6. Player housing, nothing massive, just a personal little house you can decorate! Would mean a lot.

7. Let us sleep in beds/sit on chairs. :>

8. Minigames on the computer within the HUB? Just a thought!

9. Let us climb the space elevator. >=(

Nonetheless, amazing game. Still having fun and doing my own thing, amazing stuff!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I rarely ever give a review out for games, but for this one, I know I had to.

First things first, this game is beautiful. Coffee Stains Studio should be so proud of the stunning and captivating environments they've been able to produce! Whether you're under the heat of a vast and sparse desert, or relaxing on the coast line underneath an alien tree, you're going to find something to love in this game.

Secondly, the game play is nearly perfect. Sure, there are some areas of the map that you might wander into that lead to a dead end (or in a couple of cases me falling through the map) but those instances make up 0.00000000000001% of your game play experience. Coffee Stain Studios have truly perfected the Open-World-Survival Sim theme and executed it in the most satisfactory (hehe) way possible.



Buy this game. Do yourself a favor and sink into the immersion and the details that these wonderful devs have made. From this game alone, I will forever be a Coffee Stain Studios fanboi.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Warning! If you would like to have a safe and healthy life by not having a video game direct your life, then this isn't the game for you; it is that addicting in my opinion.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes to watch machines work for them and just loves automation. There really isn't much more that I can say about this game; it is that good.

Just within the first 2 days of owning this game, I have never felt a feeling of such satisfaction by playing a video game and branching out an industry of large proportions. I hate grindy games, but this game gives a sense of high accomplishment for doing grindy tasks.

For anyone familiar with Minecraft Modpacks that revolve around anything technology based, this isn't like anything you've seen; it is actually fun to build machines and automation processes without hassel of having to beat around some other bush to gather materials for one simple machine.

If anyone has played NMS, this game gives a vibe with it, but with its own creative spin. No stupid Alchemic processes of turning X into Y, then Y into Z, no dumb story that makes you run around like a headless chicken, and no stupid power required to actually run storage systems.

As a closing to this cluster review, I believe the best characteristic of this game that gives it such a good feeling of progression is that you really don't need any walk-through's, wiki's, or a discussion site to actually play the game. You can still use these sources, but you rarely will need them; I've only gotten stuck once and needed Wiki help for obtaining an item.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game has a bunch of random mechanics that are fun individually , but as a factory building sim I can't say that it's really that great. Honestly, Factorio is just a better factory construction game and feels more gratifying to play, this game really doesn't hit the same notes. Whenever I finish some part of my factory in this game I just think "Thank Gaben that's been dealt with" rather than "What's next?" like Factorio. The game has no core drive for me, it doesn't really feel fun to build new facets of my factory, it just feels like a chore. The infinite resources means there's no conflict to drive you forward and build elsewhere, you just build and then let it sit on it's own for 5 Hours until you finally reach the next research threshold and can move on to... doing the exact same thing, again... ... It's really not that great, especially since I'm comparing it to a Titan like Factorio.

I hope this game can improve in the future, as individually its parts are fun, but as a whole... It's definitely less than the sum of its parts...

5/10, like exactly dead average overall, individual mechanics would be better served in a better, more satisfactory, game.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This has potential to be a great game. Subnautica meets Factorio, what's not to like? There are many things the devs have done right, and a few that need work, but for an early access game, it's definitely a recommendation from me.

What works:
- Visuals are great.
- Factory building is very enjoyable, the models are simply amazing and the core systems are fun.
- Technology progression feels rewarding so far.
- Exploration is surprisingly good for a factory-building game. The decision to avoid procedurally generated maps and go for a few hand-crafted worlds is the right one here, and the maps are fantastic, although rather small. They are interesting to explore and invoke a sense of wonder.
- Surprisingly few glitches for early access. Aside from some placeholder items here and there, I wouldn't be able to tell right away that it's not a finished product.

What needs work:
- The major issue that bugs me personally is complete lack of an end-game goal. Without something to look forward to the game feels pointless. This is subjective, but I prefer my sandbox games to give me something big to work towards, even if it's superficial like in Minecraft. Maybe I've missed something, but I'm halfway through the technology tree and I still have no clue why I'm building all this stuff. Bugs the hell out of me.
- Balance needs some work. E.g., until you hit the coal power (which is pretty late if you don't know what you're doing in advance), power management is a major hassle as you're forced to constantly cut trees for fuel, which feels like a grind. In a way, it's good that the game forces you to do it early on to encourage exploration, but to my taste it does it too much.
- Buildings placement in 3D is fiddly. I think something like easily adjustable snap-to-grid scale setting would be very useful.
- For a game of complex flowsheet management it lacks the tools to visualize it. I'd love to see some in-game screens that would allow to understand what is not working at a glance.
- Lack of some kind of blueprint system to allow for simpler base expansion. This is a highly requested feature, which as I understand the devs are not keen on implementing. It doesn't bother me too much personally, but I know many people suffer without it.

Mind you, none of these issues prevent me from having a ton of fun with this game.

Have been playing fro over 1200 hours and there is still so much to do, build and explore.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's a factory building game like Factorio. In contrast to Factorio this game has a fully realized 3D world and this is a problem. The main game loop revolves around building various factory elements and the 3D world makes it difficult and tiresome to build those. In the 2D world of Factorio the act of lining up the buildings or removing swaths of constuction elements is easy and here it's a chore. You will spend some time designing your factory and a lot of time trying to align a conveyor belt against a constructor or something like that. The 3D nature of the world and FPS aspect of the game make it very unpleasant experience.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Game is incredibly addicting. Completing one portion of your factory unlocks new potential for more and more lines, which then double back and allow you to work on building the efficiency of your already existing line. Game has got a bit of jank on it, but nothing game breaking, just some goofy clipping and materials in game that have no use (which helpfully tell you they have no use as of yet). Movement feels very good, problem solving results in satisfying conclusions. A great big world to explore and so much iron to mine. I can see myself spending hundreds of more hours into this, and the devs seem to be actively working on more content.

If you enjoy base building, problem solving, creating efficient systems and watching things go past on conveyor belts, you'll enjoy this game.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
There are times where I absolutely hate this game. The random frame rate hiccups have lead to my death (multiple times). Once you get past a certain sized base, the game can really start to chug (to the point of unplayable). I have also encountered a weird glitch where when I exit the game, the game doesn't actually shut down. It continues to run in the back ground, and I cannot shut it down without restarting Steam.

Then there are SO many parts of the game I love. Everything is your creation. Whether your base works or fails it's all on you. And it feels SO GOOD to have your plans and designs work. It's a wonderful and addicting gameplay loop. The updates are regular and often substantial. The atmosphere is great, and the world can feel foreboding and mysterious.

This game can endlessly piss me off, but I have so much fun with it, I'm more than willing to put up with the issues, and I feel like the developers will get this game finished and polished.

In short, there are points where I pause, look at the world and what I've created, and think "Wow. I can't believe this is still in early access." And then my character gets stuck in a rock and I think "Oh yea. This game is in early access."

Set your expectations appropriately, and you will have a good time.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Do you have OCD?
Yes: Well you'll love this game because tediously designing, micromanaging, min/maxing, adjusting and readjusting your factory will satisfy even the most meticulous of people.
No: Don't worry, the game is forgiving enough/free enough to allow for total spaghettification of your designs... just don't expect it to be easy to find things down the line.

Do you like stunning visuals?
Yes: Well you're in luck, complete with beautiful scenery, high texture quality, and even lense flare this game is graphically quite stunning.
No: mmm IDK, try Minecraft maybe?

Do you like active combat?
Yes: Well this probably isn't the game for you, there is PVE combat, and you could even say it's virtually essential to progress in the game, it isn't the core intention of the game, there are things to kill yes (as mentioned things you pretty much have to kill, yes), and there are melee and firearms, but not many, and none are particularly powerful and satisfying to a violence addict.
No: See above, you will need to fight things most likely, I can't imagine a method of play that doesn't involve killing some creatures, but don't worry, you aren't going to be on a battlefield.

Do you like Spiders?
Yes: Oh good! Then you'll love the caves...
No: Well no worries, you can turn them into.... kittens? Nasty, mean little kittens...

Overall:
Game directive: Creative building and design, encourages creative engineering to build a factory capable of achieving several goals.
Rating: A+ for visual qualities, beautiful scenery, realistic machinery, most graphical elements of this game are top notch.
Rating: A for Control interface/User Interface, although most things are relatively intuitive and movement feels smooth, dynamic, and predictable, there are some aspects of the controls that aren't exactly well explains, such as stack splitting, etc... honestly just look up the controls, it's not Arma 3 complicated or anything, but there are a few controls that the average user may not even know exist.
Rating: A+ for depth of gameplay, honestly you can sink easily over 500 hours into a single factory and still not be fully "satisfied" (although personally I only get about 50 hours into a factory before my ADD kicks in and I move on to something else, but I come back repeatedly)
Rating: A for replayability, there is only 1 map, but the map is in all honesty, absolutely huge, there are 4 main starting locations and with some hiking you can choose your own starting location by just breaking down your escape pod and walking for a bit, however there are probably some places that will be difficult if not impossible to use as a start location due to 1: impassible terrain until later in the game, 2: potential baddies between you and where you want to go and/or 3: access to basic resources that are definitively required for progress on nearly any level of the game. To be frank I have restarted the game 4 times and loaded into all but 1 of the 4 starting areas (I visited the other one in one of my previous games and it's a bit creepy there, so I don't want to live there...) and despite restarting the game that many times I have yet to traverse the whole map, but the developers did do a great job of gently encouraging you to visit other areas by spreading out end-game resources.
Early Access Rating: A+ (some may not share this view), as opposed to releasing frequent yet unimpressive updates the developers have chosen to use large scale updates less often, they roll bug fixes quite regularly, but full feature updates are generally fewer in number, but great in overall addition to the gameplay. As far as the state of the game goes I have to say every aspect of the game that is in play right now feels finished minus a few odd items here and there (the odd thing that doesn't have sound attached to it for example, like construction of a vehicle), but otherwise the playable elements of the game right now, feel complete and well polished. We're so used to "Early Access" games being a catch all phrase for under developed and unfinished crap with no curb appeal or at the very least several massively game breaking bugs, Satisfactory is not one of those games.

Buy it?
Yes buy it if the Q&A at the top sounds appealing to you.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Pros:
-good graphics
-well designed maps, beautiful + no out of place clipping etc.
-amazing game play, especially if you're mechanically inclined.
-very easy to setup multiplayer, was able to jump right in with no issues.
-no major bugs or glitches that I've had to experience yet.

Cons:
-not very many different maps, which I would assume can cause game play to eventually stagnate. [Edit] At the time of making this I didn't realize there was only one map. But I see now that it is a large single map, with many possibilities. So if it's a negative or not is in the eye of the beholder.

Maybe could add variants of ore etc. to add a splash of variation to the game, but other than that I can't think of anything I dislike.

Overall, I think this game provides a mechanically/statistically challenging environment in a way that still offers the relaxation and entertainment of playing a video game you enjoy. Would definitely recommend. 8.5/10

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It is a high quality game but Factorio is its' superior in quality and technicality. Satisfactory is good if you played a lot of Factorio and want something new otherwise stick with or play that game. Because of the inclusion of the 3rd dimension building something as simple a conveyor belt can have a lot of depth in comparison to Factorio but as a tradeoff it is much more sluggish and tedious especially at first. Progression in this game is slow and not incredibly gratifying in comparison to Factorio where even early on it feels rewarding to get machines to work in this it is just connect the dots. They put too much emphasis on the later stages of the game.

A really unfortunate part of this game however is the performance problems, framerate can dip from time to time but mainly I mean the poor performance when playing online with friends. If two people living a few blocks from each other with really great internet and decent systems can't even walk around without horrific latency you have a problem. It is unacceptable how poorly this stuff works. For some reason as well your character is saved on the cloud so if for whatever reason you try to play your world when you are offline you will find your inventory is wiped and vise versa. It thinks online you and offline you are two different characters which is beyond stupid.

So in short play Factorio instead unless you played all you can of that game and want something new.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is a game that appears to be a direct descendant of Factorio, in that the primary challenge and the main point of the game is to create factories and supply lines between them that would wring the planet out of its natural resources and turn them into technological products that you need to create more sophisticated factories, more efficient supply lines, and more cool gadgets for personal use. On that front, Satisfactory delivers while still being in deep Early Access, there's hundreds of hours of content.

What puts it apart from other similar games, by which I mostly mean Factorio, is that Satisfactory puts you in the first-person perspective in a very gorgeous and vertical world. There are so many hidden nooks and crannies to find while scaling monumental mountains with waterfalls falling into the mist below. The real joy of Satisfactory comes from its movement: by creating the gargantuan machine of your factory, you create an environment for yourself to traverse, and boy is it ever a joy to traverse it. Electric ziplines, exoskeletons, parachutes, and jetpacks are all valuable additions to your character, who gets to bullet jump like in Warframe and slide under conveyor belts. It is so far removed from the central point of the game, but the game would be so much worse off if it wasn't included. If you're reading this, you probably know all about the factory-building aspect, but there is a lot more to this game than conveyor belts and iron plates.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game has been on my radar for a bit. There was no way in hell I was going to buy it during its Epic exclusivity period, so I waited for the Steam release. While the game is still in early access, it's certainly more feature complete than a majority of other titles in that category can boast.

Anyway, what do I think? It's good; addictive. It's easy to come across production issues and have to problem-solve around them to squeeze maximum efficiency out of your setups. It's also common to find yourself tumbling down rabbit holes of exponentially expanding production possibilities. For example, I went into a rebuild of my current manufacturing base, expecting only to increase steel and component throughput. I'm now finding myself demolishing everything in that base because I realized I wasn't maximizing my miners. It's opened up a ridiculous list of ways my production efficiency is about to increase, and I'm not even optimal yet.

If you like to obsess over details and squeeze every single bit of efficiency out of things, this game will likely not disappoint you.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
If you are a fan of Factorio, you will LOVE this game. If you are not a fan of Factorio, you will LOVE this game. Okay, maybe not LOVE, but there is still a lot to like about Satisfactory. First of all, it is still in Early Access and there is sooo much to do. You will likely not finish all the tiers before the next update, which will bring even more content. There is not even a story mode yet, but there is story mode promised in a future update, and frankly, I don't see how they can fit it in with all the other stuff to do. My factory is a tangled mess, but that's just how I play. I still love tearing down what I have and rebuilding it. Don't get me wrong...you don't have to tear everything down and rebuild. There are ways to play without completely redesigingin everything, but if that's what you want to do, hey, go for it. Loving this game and can't wait to see what is coming down the road!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is such a fun game that I always find myself coming back to. Anyone who likes factory games such as Factorio will probably love Satisfactory as well. Unlike many factory building games, Satisfactory is first person, making it even more satisfying to step back and watch as your factories grow. The main gamplay of building your factory and advancing your technology is very fun, because you can put in the time to carefully plan out your factory and make it look clean and organized, without it becoming overly tedious. On top of factory building, Satisfactory also has an element of world exploration which can serve as a nice break if you want to focus on something other than building factories for a while. The world exploration is well done because it allows you to explore the rather large map and see all the interesting and beautiful biomes, while also getting Hard Drives which give you valuable alternate recipes for your production lines. On top of the fun core gameplay, Satisfactory can also be played in singleplayer or multiplayer. I find the game to be fun in singleplayer, but even more fun if a couple of friends join your world. One thing to note is that if you join a multiplayer game you often experience more bugs than in singleplayer, but these bugs are almost never game-breaking and can normally be fixed by rejoining the world. Also, the game is still in early access and is quite smooth considering it is not fully released. Satisfactory also seems to never get old. I have put many hours into the game and still plan to put in many more. I constantly think about future factory plans and have loved every second of playing the game. In all, Satisfactory is a very fun and satisfying factory game that I would recommend to anyone who already likes factory games, or to anyone who hasn't played a factory game and wants to try out the genre.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is an excellent game for people who like building bases. It's all about building.
Having said that, I must say the world is gorgeous. It's an alien planet with multiple moons and a day-night cycle. There's lots of terrain to explore in search of raw materials and some local fauna to battle for control of territory, though combat is only a small part of the game.
The interface is also very good. There's something intuitive about pointing where you want to build something then seeing all the materials fly from your person to that spot and assemble the building in seconds. It just feels right.
The focus is always on building your factories bigger and better. Rerouting the endless streams of conveyor belts to be more efficient and watching them march long lines of materials across the landscape to be gobbled up by your ever-hungry factories. Ship your products off to your overseers in space to unlock more building schematics then build your factories bigger and better than before.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is very fun and extremely "satisfactory". Most of this game is not in completing challenges, but in creating more efficient and beautiful factories. This is where the gameplay shines as you have to figure out what is holding back your machines and rebuilding time and time again to keep up with your resource demand.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants an amazing base builder and a lot of extra hours to put into it.

The only thing I can say against this game is the lack of optimization for multiplayer and the lack of being able to run a dedicated server. But from what I hear, these issues are being worked on (even if they are not the highest priority).

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is a really fun and addictive automation factory-builder. The combat and exploration elements are pretty basic but kinda fun. There are some issues with scalability - there's no functioning blueprint system for example like factorio has, which means you end up spending a lot of time building big rows of production buildings and individually hooking up each one to input, output, and power. But I got a LOT of fun out of this game before this really started to bother me. I will also say that the hand-built map, while beautiful, limits replayability. It's quite unbalanced in terms of resource locations too. There is a particular spot that is essentially the objectively best place to start your factory to avoid having to make massive long-range transportation lines, so if you want to start fresh you're kinda short on reasonable alternatives to that spot without making everything more difficult than it needs to be.

Despite this review mostly consisting of complaints there is no way I would not recommend the game. Hundreds of hours of fun to be had even in it's current early access state.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Do not buy this game. It's a freaky time warp thing. You'll sit down after breakfast to play just an hour or two, you just want to tweak the efficiency on your power before you start your irl Saturday chores, then suddenly it's bedtime. You didn't even get to the power supply; you needed to fix the line feeding this thing into the space elevator, which brought you to the next tier, which allowed you to get the thing you've been just dying to get, plus your sink had enough tickets to get this thing you want, but now you need to feed pricier things into the sink to get the next cool thing, so you had to build a line feeding X thing in...

If you buy this game it's going to steal so many hours out of your life.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I have played over 500 hours on Epic. I have done multiple playthroughs of the content available in current early access. I really enjoy this game.

There is exploration. A whole seperate adventure that you can undertake at your pace.

There is building. Lots of building. Lots of freedom of how to setup your style.

There is fighting. But you can completely eliminate this if you dont want it.

The progression keeps going and feels rewarding.

This is not a high thrills game. This is best played at your own pace. For creative people you can really go out of your way to create "pretty" structures. For logical people. You can really be efficient about how you do stuff. I can recommend completing each stage fully before rushing onto the next thing. A solid production line of the early things helps with the later things.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I love open world sandbox games. Minecraft and redstone circuitry were always my favorite part of the game. Enter Satisfactory, where you can harvest and mine resources to build ever-increasing complexity contraptions! While there isn't a story mode yet, I love the ability to find new ways to build out my base and maximize my efficiency. The modding community around the game is awesome, providing both neat quality of life improvements (like the ability to monitor your factory efficiency and belt capacities, as well as whole new sets of building components to better align with what's being built) as well as functional changes with new components, like lift elevators that you can use to move vertically up and down your building without the need of hyper tubes.

My only complaint thus far about the game is that the map, while huge, is static. Every time you load up a new game, you'll be playing on the same map. The resource nodes are always in the same place, the collectibles are always in the same place, etc. If I could take the open world space exploration of a game like Elite Dangerous, the base building and terrain manipulation capabilities of games like No Man's Sky, and have the resource mining and factory simulation of Satisfactory, I'd never play another game again again.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
We all know it. We see Early Access and roll our eyes. The grim reminder in our libraries of how we got burned by trusting: "The game will be finished soon, We promise this and that and all that absolutely soon".

And then they are the glimpse of hope like Rimworld, or in this case Satisfactory.

Satisfactory, the satisfaction of developers to show others how to handle the brand of Early Access.

There is no nonsense roadmap with "set in stone" dates. You don't get meaningless updates every week to get you false hope of progress.
There is on other hand a good communication with community and lot of ways how to give feedback.
This whole thing is handled the satisfactory kind of way, the professional way.

The Good: it look satisfying, sounds satisfying. I have encounter single crash in SP (note on experimental branch), progress/exploration/fun factor, oh you know it = satisfying.

The Bad: MP is unstable, crashes a lot. Some visual issues - tied for me to AntiAliasing with foundations (fixed by turning it off, yet got blinded by sun reflection time to time).
Some small bugs and visual imperfection (tied to EA status) like certain equipment clipping and similar, but for me nothing game breaking and the game runs more smoothly than some AAA full released games (hello Batman).

So watch some LetsPlayes and if you are intrigued by this game, dont hesitate - As a rare gem, this game is worth your money as it was with mine. With a little bit of polish this game could be released and be worth more than it cost now.

Join us.
We work for Factory now.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I played 340+ hours, do you actually need to know anything else?
Okay, so this game is very addictive, offers such a rich variety of things to do, things to build, things to improve.
I mostly play together with a friend and we rarely run into any issues (trains a bit tricky to handle for the client). However, we ran into some performance issues recently but to be fair, our factory is quite large – I wonder what the total length of our conveyor belts is. The developers are updating this game constantly, so I'm sure they'll find a way to fix the remaining bugs easily :)

I would honestly buy this game a second and a third time to support this game and the developers further (which I actually do by gifting it to friends on their birthdays :D).

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is called Satisfactory for a reason. I never enjoyed building in games like Minecraft, Terraria, or city building games, but this game makes building so satisfying it makes you want to do more and more and build something designed for yourself. I can't wait for this game to get out of early access and see what new things and how the world will be populated more - already it's a beautiful game with its core mechanics flushed out. Less bugs than full released games I've played.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
No way around it, this is just an excellent game. A must-have for anyone who enjoys Factorio. It's well-polished. Like, every machine has it's own special animation polished. Placing down large buildings feels amazing and truly like you are getting more powerful as you progress through the game. It is addicting, and keeps you engaged.

My only complaint is how grindy the super super late game gets. And by that, I specifically mean the Assembly Director System. At this point in the game I'm not motivated enough to manually place down all the parts required to make these in a decent amount of time. I basically just left the game idling at night for a few days. I'd like to see a tweak to that recipe or maybe automated factory construction.

Either way, I can't wait to see what this game becomes. Coffee Stain - you guys have something great on your hands. Keep up the great work!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I want to say that this game is amazing and beautiful, and I plan on sinking many, many more hours into this game. That aside, there are some ideas, some useful and some aesthetic, that I think would make this game even cooler.

- Alarm systems. These can trigger sounds if you reach a certain threshold of power usage, items in a storage container, water reservoir depletion, pre-set time like a stopwatch, or have it constantly sounding the alarm. Bonus points if the alarm has a rotation light animation can be colored at the light control panel.
- Industrial decor. For example, cardboard boxes, crates, stacks of metal sheets, bundles of tubes, and pallet stacks to put these decor items on. This would be great for warehouse themed builds.
- Green decor. Planter beds, etc., for foundations. Trees, shrubs, flowers, etc., for the foliage decor. These can give further crafting uses to leaves, flowers, and wood.
- Computer system that catalogs your production, power usage per buildings (constructors, smelters, etc.) and panels (building blocks that go on walls) that can display whatever information you wish them to display.

Of course the devs can do and will do whatever they want, but I think these things would be cool. Either way, this game is great. Highly recommend.

I have never put in so many hours into a single game before. To say this game is addicting is an understatement. The developers at Coffee Stain studio have really outdone themselves on this one and have done extremely well listening to their customers and implementing good feedback. EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
The game is awesome. Addicting, engaging (but not urgent) pace, great levels of abstraction, and a healthy dose of "figure it out yourself" lack of instruction later on. Perhaps that last point about the tutorials is because it's in test, but there's something satisfying about figuring out how to be an effective player on your own.

Cons: Really the only cons i have are with the current state, and it seems they've put off on some of the simpler issues to focus on mechanics. Things like:
- buggy af mobs
- haven't really implemented model collisions
- automated pathing buggyness
- plz default the cursor to the text form when selecting a search operation

current conclusion:
great work on the developers part, and the prioritization of the game feature rollouts. Can't wait to see what they add/patch next!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
So I'm leaving this as a don't recommend as the game needs to make some pretty major strides to be much more than "grinding in 3D Factorio". There's basically no challenge unless you do what I did and travel far, lose your starting weapon and then build next to enemies... Then you'll spend an hour being miserable just because you can't defend yourself.

Other than that... I just don't see where the challenge is. There's no real presence to work against. Like in Factorio (which was also too easy in my opinion) at least there's a growing enemy presence that attacks you.

Its a very pretty game, and has loads of potential... But its just not there yet.

I think once we get some sort of real enemy the game will be a lot more fun and something you'll want to play with friends. Right now... Its kinda like playing Forge in Halo alone... Its cool... You can do cool things but there's no challenge.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is my Minecraft redstone automation dreams on crack with great graphics to boot. 48 hours in and only crashed once, for an early access game it exceeded my expectations and the environment is beautiful. Being my first proper factory-building game, I expected it to feel grindy and very focused around the factory aspect, but it didn't feel tiring at all. Keeping things neat is my priority but I'm not too overly fussed about it, you can basically go as crazy as you want to. A lot of room for different playstyles! I got addicted to automating things so that I got time to go out and explore for resources. I just started on trains and oh my god... You're telling me I can build an entire train network on this map? Now I'm REALLY obsessed. I close my eyes and I see conveyor belts. I'm constantly thinking of what to name my next train station. Looking forward to more developments on this game :)

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is very fun. I got it like yesterday and already have 10+ hours. Very addictive, lets you use your head a lot, and as the game progresses you get to see your hard-worked creation spring to life. I was hesitant to get this game for a while, I didn't see the fun in running conveyors all the time. That isn't what this game is though. You get to use your head, think about problems and solutions, and just have a great time. One of the biggest downsides to his game is the story. I don't really mind it, but if you like games with a lot of story and lore I would not recommend this. Why are you on this planet? Who is FICSIT? Why are you sending resources into the sky to unlock new things? To make him rich? If you really want story to a game don't get this one, but if you just want something that will get you going for hours, totally get this. And who knows, this is in early access currently, so maybe the game will change in the full release. This game has ups and downs but all in all, in my opinion, its just fun.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I kept waiting for this game to be fun, but most of it is sitting at a crafting menu with your mouse button held down by your headphones for 30 minutes so that you can get a slightly faster conveyor belt. Everything is tedious to do, until you play the game for a super long time to get everything automated, which at that point the game isn't even a game. It's still just sitting there, waiting for resources to pile up so you can unlock slightly faster conveyor belts, letting you make faster automation for the same purpose. It's just a cycle of boring grinding. The exploration of the world basically consists of standing at your base waiting to unlock a scanner upgrade, using the scanner, making a beeline to the ore that you scanned for, and going back to base after setting up a miner for the ore. I can see how people might be able to have fun with this with friends, but it's so overpriced that you would have a hard time convincing them to essentially get an idle game. I liked astroneer, which is also an automation game, but in astroneer, you're dealing with about 5 resources at a time, tops. In this game, some of the objectives are something like "get 2500 copper wire" which takes about 20 minutes to even craft. They're obviously different games, but for the same price one is so much less tedious than the other. There's clearly been lots of planning, time, and care put into all the aspects of the game, but it's just not fun, and it doesn't do enough with its expansive map until far too late in the game.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Wonderful visuals and well paced progression make this a very addictive game.

Although I have not finished the lush starter world (still have tier 8 & 9 to complete), I have to admit I'm thoroughly addicted by this promising early access game.

Visually, the game is stunning, and I'm constantly distracted by the unique panoramas the game has to offer. The various machines used to craft everything are interesting enough to keep you from being bored looking at your creations. Perhaps, the only thing I found clumsy was the limited shapes and lack of various textures for the foundation blocks.

As far as game play goes, there is a good mix of building manufacturing plants and transportation systems and the need to go exploring for new resources. However, I did find that it took way too long to get a decent weapon (rifle) but, apparently, you're supposed to be building stuff. I really like the various vehicles and personal enhancements you get as you progress. I can't wait to try the hover pack, and just hover around everywhere.

Recommended.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is definitely unique, but loses its charm relatively quick. The whole idea of automating resource collection over time is a great idea, but everything else about it kills the vibe. I'm sure they'll make more maps in the future but there's currently only 1 & it doesn't change... All nodes, enemies, etc are in the same locations, "Multiplayer" is severely lacking, has many bugs, & with extreme limitations of hosting it's almost impossible to have it run by a dedicated server. Based on gameplay Satisfactory was meant to be more of a singleplayer game since many of the bugs I've seen occur in multiplayer, but at this time I can't see myself playing solo since there's next-to-nothing else to do. There's really no "exploration" other than the map itself (no cave systems, etc), & "survival" is, well, there may as well be no enemies.

Do I recommend it? Not really. Until more gets implemented it sort of remains broken, & the unchanging map, along with lack of any story, makes multiple playthroughs quite monotonous & boring.

I gave it an honest try... 330 hours just trying different things. I had hoped to find something more than simply building the same stuff over & over... & over. I've since uninstalled it until a later date. I'll renew this review after 2022 when it's slated to leave early access. Perhaps bug fixes with multiplayer, an added storyline, a dedicated server option, implementation of the WIP devices, & more will peak my interest enough to keep me involved.

I never thought this type of game would appeal to me so much. After playing the Sevtech mod for Minecraft and interacting with similar systems, I discovered that yes, I do enjoy things like this.

This game is very relaxing and enjoyable. Half the time I play this game I'm just taken in by the music and environments. Your driving force is building, production, and refining your setups, but the surrounding nature is such a beautiful juxtaposition.

At the time of this review I'm just starting Tier 5, and have spent a great deal of time rebuilding my bases to better streamline my production and shipping of parts. I'm looking forward to what comes next in game, and in future updates.

This game? Is it? I'm not entirely sure. There seems to be a list of required skills you need to make full efficiant use of the space you are given,

Do you have a Master's Degree in Structural Design?
No.
Do You have a Master's Degree in Engineering Design?
No.
Do you like exploring planets?
Absolutely.
Do you want to see strange life?
Heck Yeah.
Do you want to see your boss every day?
*speaks quietly under their breath before answering* No.
Do you work well by yourself, or with others?
Both? Both. Both is good.

Pros
Alien World
Alien food
Magic construction tool
Beautiful
Don't need to sleep... ever
Tasks, So many Tasks.

Cons
Alien World
Alien wildlife that (outside of the giant blob tick thing and giant flying butterfly) will try to kill you every chance it gets.
Alien Food (not enough of it)
Designing your factory layout. (Master's degree needed xD)
Can't destroy all rocks (which sucks when designing)
Can die (alot)
Falling into the abyss.

All in all, this is a great and fun game/task mangler. 10/10 would fall into the abyss again to get away from these tiny flying gnat F%^$S.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This is really one of those times where I wish Steam allowed something other than a simple yes/no. There's a lot that's really great here, but I can't recommend it in its present state.

I originally had a long essay detailing various frustrating experiences I had playing Satisfactory, but after reading back it just felt like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about unfinished mechanics in a game that never purported to be anything but early access. Things like tedious and frustrating wheeled exploration in a tractor that handles like an overloaded zamboni. Or the perplexing lack of a noclip console command, when glitching into and getting stuck in terrain happens just about every game session. Or half-baked and poorly signposted game mechanics like getting caught in a "Live, Die, Repeat" scenario when I naively picked up some uranium ore and died instantly, then hiked my ass back to my corpse from a klick or so away, hit the "grab all" button in the looting UI, and died instantly again because no one outside the wiki bothered to tell me that having uranium ore in your inventory without a hazmat suit kills you in a zeptosecond. I did that maybe six times before I figured out about the ore, and had to basically do a save-scum routine to get all my stuff back.

All that said--and more besides, I assure you--I look forward to seeing where this game goes. The factory building itself is really well done. The act of building itself is very fluid and intuitive, and it's very absorbing setting up production lines and fine tuning both efficiency and use of space. The tech trees are very good at providing incentive to change up what you build and how you move and store things, and even though exploration is frustrating and more than a little chore-like, it IS gratifying to unlock a new resource and set up entire new processes for extraction, refining and manufacturing.

Also, I may be reading more into it than is there, but I think I detect a subtle sort of commentary about consumerism and the environment in the gameplay itself. You mine, transport and expand only so you can make more parts with which to mine, transport and expand. You run around ceaselessly looking for biomass to fuel your reactors, cutting down whole forests and denuding caves of mushrooms. You'll find yourself exterminating local fauna not because they drop precious resources, but because they're a nuisance when you're trying to build power transmission lines or resource-transporting conveyor belts. From what I can see, only certain resources have spawn rates, and for the most part plant and animal life is not among them. So eventually you'll see your factory at the center of a lifeless zone, forever expanding and assimilating everything in its path. It's damned clever if it's intended.

Altogether, I'd definitely say keep your eyes on it, but for now pick it up on a pretty steep sale, or if all the good stuff I mentioned seems worth the substantial frustrations of early access.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Factorio in 3D with a bit different mechanics. Some are better, some are worse. That is all what you need to know about this game.
All the advantages of this game are described in other reviews.

I want to point out four main flaws in the game that did spoil the gameplay for me.

1. Lack of challenge.
It has no Biters. Nothing threatens you, nothing to defend from. You just build for the sake of building. In time it becomes boring.
Of course there are hostile wild animals, but they do not possess any real threat. They also do not attack your buildings.
Biters are very essential part of the Factorio (I compare Satisfactory to Factorio because the core game mechanics are the same), which adds flavor to the the game and makes it much more interesting. Satisfactory lacks it, unfortunately.

2. Poor optimization for massive multilevel factories.
In the beginning of the game I had 90-120 fps. When I built my 3 floor factory my FPS dropped to 40-45. And I just climbed to Tier 5 out of 8.

3. UI for building is not really good.
You can't make any little adjustments to already built <anything>. You can't change angle, rotate or move. This is very annoying when you have to rebuild from scratch conveyors or electric poles because you initially incorrectly placed them on few centimeters.
Connecting conveyors in the distance is a pain. You have to point very precisely otherwise it wont connect or it will connect to the wrong direction.
Connecting power lines is also a pain. Until you research MK2 electric poles in pretty late middle game you are stick to poles with 4 connections which is a very frustrating. You have to put poles everywhere. It is so annoying.
No blueprints or tools for mass construction. Building large amounts of assemblies is mundane and repetitive.
And other minor issues that frustrates you.

4. The world around you is vast and beautiful but besides collecting energy slugs in reality you have no reason to explore it. Nothing to do there, nothing to collect there.
