EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
THIS GAME IS AMAZING!!!!!! I don't know if it's just me, but for the last few years I feel there has been a real lack of imagination when it comes to game making. There has been some very big name game releases that I have looked forward to, and yet once they get released and you play for a few days or so, you've played through it all and these developers now-a-days TOTALLY FORGET ABOUT THE GAMES. They make their big chunk of money on the release and never go in and update content or add new things. These big companies release these huge games with so much potential, but they're only out for a dollar. Even if/when they release updates.. they want you to pay stupid amounts of money for them, and if you don't then you are left with a very vanilla game.

This game however, is constantly coming out with releases and new updates... I have put in close to 200 hours and I am still learning something new everyday, and there's soooooo much more to unlock! I've put that 200 hours in and that's just the first game I started with! There are more maps!!! I think you could truly spend a lifetime playing this game and still have things to do and learn.. and it's still in the early release stage!!!!!

I haven't been addicted to a game like this in years.. it brings back memories of the old COD Modern Warfare and Battlefield 3 days when ALL responsibilities went to the side because I couldn't put enough hours in! First time in a long time I have rushed home to play a game.. it actually gives me something to look forward to!! Even at work I am sitting there thinking of ways to improve my systems and what I'll do next!!!!!

GET THIS GAME, BUT BE WARNED YOU WILL NEVER WANT TO STOP!!!!

Big shout out to the mods and developers who continue to put time into this game and have finally sparked my gaming passion again! I would buy this game 10x over again, and not even for the new content.. but out of the principal that you can tell these guys want to make us happy and ensure we continue to love the game! That's worth something!

BUY IT!!!!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
At the time of writing this, the game has a "Overwhemingly Positive" rating. I feel this is overly generous. So to balance it out I will vote to not "recommend". Steam, please change your voting system.

Like other and very few negative reviews have pointed out, and I feel this is a bit unfair, but we live in the real world where a different game and probably the inspiration for this game exists, by the name of Factorio. Factorio is a game that better captures the essence of what Satisfactory is trying to accomplish.

What do I mean by this? Well, you need to place down buildings and transport stuff between them using conveyors, right? So this translates into a space management problem and playing this game in first person is a fatal flaw. It's very difficult to judge space in first person. This is why in real life we use things like plans on a piece of paper, which allows us to allocate space easily. It's like the idea started a gimmick: What if we could see our Factorio factory in first person, wouldn't that be cool? And then they made the game that way, missing the entire point. It's a step backwards down in game mechanics. If they add a top down view via a drone and a out of the box grid system, it would help greatly.

I found the game to be much simpler than Factorio, but way more tedious. Especially with manually having to collect fuel leaves to power your installation. You can't even hold it down. You have to hit your use key on every single flower. And you need THOUSANDS of them. My finger actually started to hurt. That can't be good for my hands...

It's not a bad game. It's better than average. It's probably even good. But it's definitely not "overwhemingly" so. It's not overwhemingly anything.

7 / 10

I can't express how great this game is. This is a true masterpiece of game development and is worth every dollar.

You can see yourself grow in this game, not just through the progression of the tier system but also through your own logic and problem solving skills. Each production line you set up will be better and you eventually see the pitfalls of your original implementation. You then can choose to refactor the setup completely or make slight adjustments to improve efficiency.

It is an amazing brain exercise. I can't remember the last time a game made me pull out a piece of paper to calculate and design something to be done in game.

If you have even the slightest interest, I say... just do it! You won't regret it.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's okay.

It's not as refined as factorio and there seems to be a prevailing belief that the player wants to redesign their factories about 8 times before the end of the game.

Belting, splitting and merging could be handled better because certain resources like screws get used A LOT and the belts can't keep up in a single line and multi line are a pain in the ass to implement compared to factorio.

I'm not sold on the alternate recipes being "discovered" on hard drives. I feel like you should be able to research them or buy them from the sink shop to help reduce the randomness.

Game is still Early access. Single player is okay, but multi-player, it's noticeable. Lots of texture glitches with belts, rendered water that will kill you if you jump into it and areas you can fall through the map, make you not want to explore because you can lose everything in your inventory.

But of course you have to because of the Hard drive and power slug system.

7/10 single player
5.5/10 multiplayer

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
At the time of this writing, this is the only game I'm playing. It's been a two months since I've played another another game. I probably should play something else to avoid burn out.

So thinking about playing another game then makes me think of all the things I need to do in the game. I actually have a task list written down on what I want to accomplish. That usually goes to hell when I get into the game and get distracted by something else I wanted to do. This game really focuses on efficiency of the machines you chain together but I'm definitely not running at 100% efficiency ;).

So the building aspect of this game is good but I'm not that good with design and mostly just stick with square and rectangle shaped buildings. The features of the game that I love the most is product automation and logistics. Regarding the latter, trains was a big game changer for me. This has allowed me to consolidate all the items I have in different parts of the world and I'm working on my first mega base too.

If any of this is what you like then this is the game for you and I hope this review helps you make that decision to play.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I enjoyed some of my time in Satisfactory, but I never got past tier 4 industry because I felt gated behind... building a factory. I enjoy the progression and the exploration, but I don't actually enjoy the factory-building portion of the game. The size of the machines and my closeness to them makes placement and arrangement difficult and tedious for me. I think the game would be greatly improved by a build mode in which is more like a city-builder top-down view. Of course I've heard that there's some kind of hover building thing later, but I haven't gotten to it. Maybe if that was moved to earlier in the progression I could enjoy the factory building.

Moreover there seems to be no overarching reason for progression and factory building other than for their own sake. There's no goal, no real threats (i.e. the bug attackers in Factorio), no point to doing anything other than the enjoyment of doing it.

Great game with incredible art design and performance. But personally I found it difficult to really enjoy.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A critically addicting factory building sandbox with a dash of exploration and crazy environments. The game's progression system is brilliantly implemented in a way that makes sure you always have a goal to work towards, but enough freedom in how you want to accomplish it that you never lose the feel of a sandbox experience. Once you get the swing of the mechanics and start unlocking more buildings, tech, and cool gadgets, the game takes a thrilling spin and becomes a huge management sim of the coolest type.

Can't recommend enough, just be prepared to waste many, many evenings away trying to perfect the efficiency of your Heavy Modular Frame factory.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
As of update four, this is the most fun game I've ever played. Exceeding my expectations. There are some annoying things about the game. How the environment is not yet destructible. That is my soul complaint. I expected it to be, considering it is a building game. I feel as if it was almost designed into the game, yet removed for now. I can play this for a very long time without realizing 9 hours went by. I usually do. This game makes me wish for improvements. To the Adventure aspects. As of right now. There are only 3 types of gathering objects that improve base(all with the same skin but different color.) There are only 3 enemy classes. Those that shoot you, those that attack you, and those that HOLY OMG WHAT IS IT (BURN IT WITH FIRE.)
And while that is fun. I would like to see further variation on enemies. As well as cute little animals you could befriend. There is only one of those.
I'd also like to see and expanse into the areas you might enjoy. So if you build until endgame (which I have NOT currently reached.) I'd like to see more opportunity/purpose/reason for building (missions, milestones, and rewards.) My current insensitive for building is OMG this is so cool. But I can imagine a game, exactly like this, that gives me incentive(in the form of more content,) as I mentioned.

So to recap. Game is a solid 9/10 or 10/10 game, even in its current version. But
You need varied enemies. Not just what it has now. (Water enemies are an idea, as well as a weapon to fight those, however those may get annoying too. So probably bad idea, just brainstorming here.)
You need more of a research tree that is harder, but gives a better reward. (It just sort of takes 3 seconds for to Finnish almost half of it and progression feels cheap. Its called "The MAM" but its a research tree.)
You need to give more options for varried buildings and building types. Its not "barebones" however, i'd love to see this game grow with a direction of say "creative mode." Or, "creative lobbies." As well as more buildable items to meet those modes head on. I believe more stuff to build would expand the world into the realm of WOW THIS IS EPIC instead of just OMG This is cool.

There are probably a million ways to improve the game, but I understand the game they gave me. I love the game they gave me. But even if you play, 24 hours or less, you'll realize, this game is AWESOME
Even if you don't have some suggestions, like me, on what they could improve, even if your critical of gameplay, even if you're thinking, should I buy this? The fun of this game, comes from playing this game. Exploring this game, and building in this game. An area you never knew, eventually becomes a base, or a part of your base. Its truly unique, as I have NEVER played a game like this. Buy this game.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Strangely addictive game play.

At first you are just running around exploring what can be done. Then you begin to realize the largest limitation is your own preconceived restrictions. There is no box... don't try to think within one.

Yes, floors can float with nothing supporting them. Floors are the key to building vertically because they allow you to build above structures without being blocked.

Automation is the key. Then you find that the amount of resources required for more advanced items will change all your ratios of items you thought you needed to build earlier.

Too addicting. Can't stop playing!!!

tl;dr Great game, great updates with more on the way. Want to multiplayer with someone.

The way the tiers work in this game is absurd. They have extremely high requirements, like an old facebook or mobile game, so it sucks up a ridiculous amount of time. You end up running around with a chainsaw to collect biofuel to use to power the generators, and its boring and monotonous.

You don't know what you need, until you need it. You need coal power, so you don't have to babysit the generators, however there's no map until later game. Jesus christ. I just spent an hour wandering through the game, not being able to pathfind properly, only to give up on the coal power, because I arrived at a node that wasn't close enough to water, because I didn't have Copper sheet rolls (or whatever they're called). Tried to find the other node and it was to difficult to get to, no map again. Finally give up and head back to main base, barely 50 rotors were constructed, need 200 for whatever upgrade.

Seriously, why are there no solar panels? Needed to consult a map online to find anything, which was irritating. This seems to cater to engineers.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Honestly, I generally don't leave reviews, but this game is interesting, addictive, sandboxy, challenging and rewarding.

Open world, survival base building, tech tree researching, resource balancing satisfaction.

You start on an alien world, dig up resources, arrange electricity, automate resources (smelting, making rods etc) then go from there, increasing your tech tree from making screws to nuclear fuel control rods.

To be honest, you won't regret playing this, not at first at least. A quick session may end up accidentally leaving you tired in the morning following 4 hours sleep.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I don't usually write reviews, but this game deserves it: everything about it is just perfect! There are so many aspects of it to keep you fully engaged: resource hunting, creating new production lines and improving old ones and unlocking new materials and recipes through the tiers, space elevator and research.

This game is masterfully crafted, there is never a moment of boredom because there is always something new to do: improving the power grid because you put down new machines that build new components, meaning you need to tweak your old production line to make it more efficient and maybe hunt down some resource nodes to upgrade your raw material input.

The progression is also very well engineered: you start from zero, having to do everything manually until you can automate the process and then, as you unlock more things, the production lines get more and more complex, requiring some clever thinking and planning to make it as efficient as possible.

There is also a multiplayer aspect, so you can build your factories with friends, even though I personally don't care for that.

And the game isn't even finished yet! But it is already so great! I very highly recommend this game!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I don't even know where to begin, this game is amazing, no need to wait for the full release, there is a ton of content to play through as is. Don't expect any story or even an in depth campaign, it's more of a sandbox with some overarching goals but chasing those goals is incredibly fun and addictive.

While the world is quite large and pretty to look at, the combat and exploration is a bit shallow, however the real meat of this game is in planning and constructing the most efficient mega factories that you can dream up. The building systems seem simple at first but as you unlock more elements to build with the possibilities open up quite a bit, throw in vehicles and all sorts of character equipment like parachutes and jetpacks for some added fun and it's a nearly perfect mix. I've been playing for over 300 hours across both steam and the original release on the epic store and I still find myself daydreaming about it all the time.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Delightfully complex and beautiful, with a rich tech tree and amazing graphics. If you want a peaceful building experience, Be sure to get the Satisfactory Mod Manager application so you can turn off enemies (search for passive mode). I love this game!

I would recommend this game because for me personally I like automation and stuff related to it. The game as well lets you do a lot of things so that you don't bored easily. I also like how the game gives you the freedom of exploring the whole world without limitations except world barrier but that's not an issue for me rn because the world is too big and I only played this game for 106hrs so there's still a lot to explore. Another one is that the game lets your build factories almost endless as well building complex factories which is also fun if your trying to build a efficient and organize factory. Lastly the best part of the game is that they have amazing animations as well models for the machines/player equipment's which is cool to watch and to look at. For me personally I would say the difficulty of this game is average because the game is not too easy and not hard. But of course it will depend on your experience if your a newbie or an expert. 4. Refined mod but instead its in the base game
5. Maybe small villages/trading stations with NPCs

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Worst $30 I have ever spent. Bought the game to play with friends and while they seem to enjoy it, I have only found a wellspring of misery in my time with the game thus far. I will give the game that the base building is generally pretty good when you are in a cooperative terrain setting but the need to trouble shoot your power supply and the resource optimization process makes this game require a Rain Man mentality that I just don't have. Everything else on the other hand...

First off, I don't think this game benefits from any way, shape, or form from being a survival game. Combat is horrendous, and makes Minecraft's look like a mechanically in depth masterpiece in comparison. Usual best policy is just to avoid it all together, but sometimes exploration forces your hand and you have to engage with this unsatisfying system. Hits feel weightless and the weapons themselves feel like parodies. Exploration itself is also deeply frustrating, with poison clouds and difficult to navigate obstacles constantly barring your path. It takes hours of work to unlock equipment to assist with the tedious expansion process and the vast majority of these tools are just useless. Vehicles struggle to navigate the terrain and provide nothing more than a few seconds of amusement from seeing the cybertruck fly through the air on the launch pad.

I really wanted to like this game, but my experiences of constant frustration with glitches and death have prevented me from finding anything more than a few fleeting moments of pleasure.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
this game is so addictive. the primary loop is fairly simple to learn and provides lots of enjoyable problem solving. i feel like i figure out a system for doing stuff... then figure out a better one for each major project i worked on. and once you get a factory setup and you're waiting for it to finish building the parts you need for the next unlock there's lots of exploration to do.

i also felt like my exploration game progressed as a series of distinct phases. and i learned different methods based on the available game mechanics. from running around on the ground... to using the truck to go explore new areas... and then using the foundations to make paths above the dangers on the ground. to using power lines and the hover pack to get to wherever i want with minimal issues from the hostiles.

the game also has some really nice quality of life features for these sorts of crafting chain setups. like giving you the items per minute values for the inputs and outputs of the building.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Among other factory games Satisfactory is very friendly and somewhat easy, - which is not a bad thing at all.
Mines never run out of resources and the wildlife never destroys your buildings, so when a production flow is established, then it can run forever.
Which is great, as you will establish a lot of production flows, ... and in good and bad that is what this game is. :-)
There is not much of a challenge or puzzle as there are plenty of resources and space. So you play this game to enjoy building huge production lines step by step in a very beautiful world. At times it can feel frustrating slow to reach the next milestone, but then relax, expand your current productions and in time that milestone will be reached.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Free at last from the evil ones and their "Exclusivity" monopoly. It's now on the platform it was meant for. The game itself is... satisfying. Once you get these production lines running and get a good power grid going, it's a great feeling. It's pretty easy to run maxed out. I get a mostly flawless 60fps at 1080p with everything on ultra with my Ryzen 7 1700 and GTX 1070. The only major con is that it stutters like a bad Unity game regardless of settings, even on several SSDs and PCs. It is early access, but man that desperately needs fixing. I just beat Valheim in it's current version's turbo stuttering, so a stutter free game would be great. Still worth it though.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
As of 20210501, I can not recommend this game to those that like this genre (Automation, exploration).

TLDR

The game has a great deal of potential to be good fun. However, the design decision to not have any sort of challenging combat mechanics, or some sort of challenging aspect that could actually cause you to lose, produces a game that is extremely superficial, mediocre, and boring.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The odds of you dying in this game are very remote (I still haven't died). The graphics are subpar for a 3D game. Sounds and Music are mediocre at best. The game mechanics are superficial and very simple. Attempting to build vertically is incredibly unrealistic in that structures do not require any support. You can have a floating base if you like.

There is no macro progression in the game either. No blueprinting. Nothing I hate more than having to repeatedly build the same design over and over.

I suggest looking elsewhere, such as Factorio, Oxygen not Included, or even Space Engineers if you really want 3D. At least those games will create some form of challenge are are by far more mechanically intricate and interesting.

90 hours in and I really can't find the fun in this game. Perhaps they will rectify this by the time they leave early access. I will check back once they do, but from what I gather so far I doubt this will happen.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Let me start by saying that I am VERY picky when it comes to beta games - generally speaking, I avoid them like the plague and over the years I have found them dis-satisfying and a waste - however I am delighted to say that is not the case with Satisfactory!

Currently gone through 2/3 games exploring different starting locations - different methods of building and the game leaves it entirely up to the played on how to manage their Factory.

Overall the gameplay is fantastic - I hope to see future PVE or monster interactions in the future, but even as it stands right now - it is an absolute pleasure which will allow you to explore and satiate all of your OCD needs. Whether you want to organize and balance all of your machines, or simply throw things together - this game has something for everyone! - and the updates keep on coming!

Cannot recommend this game enough!

At the time of posting (4.29.21) the game is a bit rough around the edges but thoroughly enjoyable. It is best described as a beautiful blend of the factory building of Factorio, the survival aspect of Minecraft, and the open-world exploration of Horizon Zero-Dawn. The graphics are great, and the overall atmosphere is akin to a walk through a dream.

There are a few things still that need improvement, namely how entities can clip through the environment (especially belts and powerlines), and that several items that currently exist in the game but serve no purpose. Judging by the rates of updates to the game I would expect both of these to be addressed before it is considered 'Completed'.

All in all, a very enjoyable game, and one I would strongly recommend.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Was definitely a bit surprised how much this game actually has to offer. Potentially one of if not the most well made factory-based automation game I've played. An immersive atmosphere on an alien planet, similar to that of No Man's Sky, but more lively. The ability to start from absolutely nothing and grow and maintain an efficient (or spaghetti mess) factory is beyond rewarding.

Though what makes this game special to me, is the ability to pause what you're doing, look up, and see a realistically scaled factory that you spent the last 10 hours or more working on. Everything animated and alive, everything towering over you with countless conveyor belts moving resources that were all placed for a reason. The game is actually beautiful, and runs incredibly well for how nice it looks. And that's just the visual aspect.

What blows my mind about this game is how in-depth it is. Not only in content, but with how much planning and math is involved to achieve what you want to do. There is a steep learning curve here, and the skill cap is practically limitless. I've spent so much time outside of the game just planning and thinking in my head or even on a notepad on how to improve my factory, how to do something more efficiently while still making it look nice. This however can be incredibly overwhelming and stressful, but playing efficiently is a preference. The game will always keep you with stuff to do, stuff to work on, stuff to plan out, and will keep your brain thinking nonstop. In my opinion this is the ultimate game of logistics.

My only complaints in the current version of the game are lack of a creative mode (place anything and plan anything with everything unlocked), and lack of reason for combat to actually exist in the game other than a research tree and filler content to do when expanding / exploring. The game has great potential to add onto combat and give it an actual purpose. Powerful items, boss enemies, using assemblers / manufacturers to craft an item to defeat a strong enemy are just a few of my own ideas. Right now combat just feels like a pointless extra, and more annoying than rewarding or fun.

Tldr; game is brilliant, beautiful, well made, fun, addictive, satisfying, and worth every penny. This is a great game if you want to keep your brain active, pass the time, enjoy basebuilding, and / or enjoy automation / logistics. It just has a steep learning curve but it's well worth the time and the progression is well made for learning how to play. This game is satisfactory.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
You looking to satisfy your building itch? You will not be satisfied. You will delete everything you built and start over with a clearly superior floor plan. Then, you will sink hours into automating everything known to man and choose which of the endless tasks available you wish to complete. And then, you'll realize you didn't understand a basic mechanic, your base is 3 kilometers from the nearest node you presently need, and you'll need to rethink and rebuild everything.
You won't be satisfied. You won't stop. Your building itch will turn into a chronic issue as you try to resist the urge to look at forums for floor plans.
If you want to give in to the need to build, this game will enable that.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is an impressively optimized factory-builder with a large focus on exploration and expansion. The progression system is very well-structured and offers a great deal of options for construction. Whether you spend hours maintaining a beautiful and organized series of factories about the map or have a single megafactory with disorganized conveyers criss-crossing about the area, you will have a lot of fun exploring and colonizing the rich environment.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Unbelievably addictive. Factorio always turned me off because of its graphics, but the "optimize ALL the things" approach is alive and well here. Lots to do, lots to explore, a real feeling of being a prospector when you venture out to find new resource nodes and try to connect them to your network... never thought this might be the kind of game for me, but holy hell did I get sucked into it.

Other positives: Great humor, beautiful enviroments and vistas, fun vehicles (mostly).

A bit more creature variety would be nice, but that's a very minor point.

Civ has "Just one more turn", this has "Just one more optimization".

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Very fun game when it comes to actually planning and creating factory lines and resource management.

The combat system is an absolute joke however. There are no real weapons and the best weapon available is a stick that you can swing at enemies twice before a 2 second cool down. There is no strategy to it at all and often times you will die to more powerful enemies over and over because there is no good way to beat them.

I have found myself spending hours spending resources to get gear to try to recover my body, only to die over and over again. The game deletes your items if you leave your session so basically if you get tired of trying to recover your body and want to quit, you lose everything.

I am giving this game a thumbs up because it is enjoyable to play when you are actually able to actually plan out a factory. The combat system is just an annoyance and it does not need to be there. This game has been out for 5 years and they still have bugs and huge needs for QOL improvements (ledge grab please!). Would recommend but there are better games of this genre out there.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is really very good, and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys puzzles, automation/factory building, and aesthetic crafting.

The factory building element is very rewarding, there is no blueprint function so everything has to be placed by hand. Some may call this tedious, but the way in which all the parts interact is important and can be done well and badly depending on how you choose to approach it. The game also includes a number of stylistic and quality of life type objects that you can unlock to enhance how things look/work.

Researching new technologies and parts is approached in 3 ways: recycling excess materials, crafting new complex parts to unlock milestones, and map exploration to find alternate recipes and new resources. The map exploration element really makes this game exciting and interesting, as you are forced to search further afield for new exotic resources to feed into your factory.

The recent update adds a proper "end game" with a stupendously complex set of recipes to craft in order to finish the game. The scaling of the technologies in general is very well done, and you always feel like the next step is challenging yet obtainable. Each milestone you unlock gives access to new parts, which normally require new recipes and layouts to add to the factory.

Multiplayer works but has some de-sync issues occasionally. The devs are very open about the fact that multiplayer is a Work in Progress, but it's still playable and really fun with friends. The solo game is also super gratifying, as everything you achieve is your own doing, and your friends can't mess up your perfectly tuned assembly line.

If you're still unsure, you'll get a good feel for the game in the first 2 hours as there isn't a lengthy scripted tutorial, so try it out and refund it if you don't like it.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Do you like engineering? Do you enjoy putting systems together, re-factor(y)ing, and making your system ever more efficient and pleasing over time? Do you have the urge to wack funky alien birds while stealing their natural habitat away from them?

If the answer to any of the above was in the affirmative, buy this game. It is indeed satisfying.

Caveat:
This game is in early access and has some issues. Personally, the most annoying of these is the frequent stuttering, which happens even on my pretty sweet PC. I have looked into this and I believe the devs mentioned that the issue stems from the way the world is streamed. Damn I hate this bug, it has killed me a number of times when fighting off some beefier creatures. However, the rest of the game feels pretty solid and I am impressed with the amount of stuff to find / build / research / craft. Hope the stutter goes away!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A game with just enough peaceful animals to make you feel bad for planetary exploitation, and just enough harmful animals to make you say ♥♥♥♥ them kids, and with just enough beautiful terrain to make you think twice about massive, ugly factories, but with just enough flat land to make you a colonialist sympathizer, this game truly brings out the worst capitalist desires of man.

With all of that being said, I really do recommend this game. It's everything younger ever wanted from those OLD old Roblox tycoon games and minecraft redstone, and its easy as hell to sink 100+ hours in. If this game looks interesting to you in any way, I would highly recommend getting it, just be prepared to neglect your friends and/or loved ones in exchange to building factories. But then again, if you find a factory building game fun then you probably have neither.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A great time-waster. As the title suggests, incredibly satisfactory. I havent played many other factory management/creation games, like Factorio, but I have played somewhat similar games like Dyson Sphere Sim., and Mindustry. Satisfactory, from what i've heard about Factorio, is a 3D version of it with more emphasis on large base building then exploration or survival. You start off at tier one, and work your way up by upgrading or completing tasks in The Hub to unlock new categories, blocks, extra inventory space, etc, and use the Space Elevator to unlock the next duo of tiers (3+4, 5+6, 7+8, etc) by sending Project Parts into it. To summarize- a crap ton of time required and a crap ton of glorious automation. I highly reccomend if you like any factory management/creation sim. Is good.
Also, the Lizard Doggo. Nothing else I need to say on that.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is - and I keep forgetting this - in Early Access. I forget this because it is not plagued with glaring empty spaces or problems like many Early Access titles are.

Satisfactory is a sandbox production / management sim in a nutshell. It can be played alone or in multiplayer online. The multiplayer though is the most obvious sign of the Early Access state of the game. Vanishing objects and UI bugs plague the multiplayer. However, it is still a good time.

When experienced in solo, Satisfactory feel remarkably polished. The visuals are nice though obviously not AAA. The movement for the player feels good. It is smooth, simple and even quite entertaining. You can slide jump (Sprint - crouch - jump - release crouch) much like in Apex Legends for quite a nice speed boost. While I'm sure this wasn't intended, it is JUST easy enough to get a taste of but just tight enough on the timing to be a good minigame to play with yourself as you move about. I am constantly slide jumping lol.

Satisfactory has a solid tutorial opening for the player (skippable but I advise playing it) and doesn't hang itself up much on having a reason to exist. They introduce you to your employer and just leave it at that, giving them some lore to make a few fun jokes with but not much else. This is nice because it doesn't get in the way but at least it exists.

The gameplay is... well, it is good. You connect machines to belts to resource nodes to other machines... and the whole thing is a giant puzzle, art project and checklist all at once. I love playing this game while chatting in discord with friends even if we all play solo. Great stuff, highly recommend.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Have you ever played a game that takes you by surprise at how good it is?

Satisfactory did that to me.

I started it in lieu of the adventures i could have on a foreign world, facing exotic wildlife and building weapons to fight them. Soon, I realised I had stopped worrying about those critters, and was more interested in whether or not my floor blocks lined up perfectly. "How can I place blocks in two different areas and line those squarely?"
Then came the period of micro factories. Then came the power cuts from over exuberant assemblers....
"Rather let me start again, now that I've learnt better methods."
Rinse, repeat, get next level of tech. "I better start again, so i can incorporate these parts into the process next time..."
and so on.

In short.

The graphics are surprisingly good, especially player movement from a 3rd person perspective.
The atmosphere is strange, weird and engaging...what one would expect when exploring an alien world.
and most importantly, The game play is fantastic and there are many many hours waiting for you with replayability only limited by your imagination.

Go on, take it. : IT the clown.

Sigh..okay, fine.
Satisfactory is amazing, okay? It scratches so many of those survival/crafty game itches and i'm so addicted to it...SO DAMN ADDICTED TO IT. Coffee Stain are working extremely hard to make this game incredible (At least, I think they are, I don't know them O_o)

It is just one of many accomplished moments you'll feel playing through the hours of content this game already has.

I could gush so much more, but..just play it, it'll prove it's point better than I.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory. For my time playing it, i have been loving it. I love the atmosphere, the mystery behind the alien landscapes, making and building your own working factory.
-
The game is all about creating a working factory on an alien life formed planet.
To get your materials you are harvesting from the natural environment, smelting the resource, and then crafting them by hand. Gathering the right quantity needed for building your working machines, making your factory, bigger, resourceful, and orderly. Making such a big factory though- is also like puzzle solving, figuring out the technical sides of it, making it all work, as well as finding the right placements for each machine so it can all work in harmony with each other.
Then-
On the other side of things.
There is the open world around you. You are surrounded by a strange, unusual alien planet. With weird plant life, creepy hostile creatures, where you either have the choice of running for your life, or fighting your way through (For more alien life formed resources...) or cute little neutral creatures, that are either shy of you, or just out right not interested. The environment is dangerous, mysterious, and keeps you asking for more, and exploring more, while your factory is working back at home.

In short - This game has a variety of everything, it is entertaining, and laborious, with a hint of combat, mystery, and excitement.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
The benchmark in factory building games

Satisfactory is an extremely fun highly rewarding game. From the beginning, being dropped onto a hostile planet with nothing but a prerecorded computer voice to guide you, the size and detail of the world will immediately draw you in. The amount of immersion the developers created is something to be cherished and is lost in a lot of games these days.

The object of Satisfactory is to explore the world, discover resources to mine, research technology to create the biggest and most optimized factory that you can. The game will give you a loose set of goals to reach in a step by step way and set you free to basically do what you want. The amount of freedom you are given to explore and build as you want is one of Satisfactory's strongest selling points.

The game is still in early access but it doesn't feel like it all. There is a mountain of content that has already been added to the game and the developers are constantly adding more as the months go by. There are some great and very detailed YouTube guides that can can watch to get you started if you feel like getting a bit of help. The feeling of adding a new wing to your factory, researching a new technology or shooting a ton of materials up a gigantic space elevator leaves you with a satisfying feeling worthy of the name of this game.

Satisfactory is definitely worth the price, actually it is an absolute steal if you like this genre of game. What will you get for your money? Hours and hours of fun whether you are planning on playing this solo or with some friends as well as a 'Ill just finish this last section and then go to bed' kind of feeling. I highly recommend giving this game a try you will not be disappointed!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Pro's:
- Has quite a lot of buildings.
- Has quite a lot of options on where to build.
- Good graphics.
- Has good potential.

Cons':
- Cannot alter terrain.
- Lack of endemic life (and variety).
- Cannot bind tools (such as weapon, chainsaw, beacons) to hotkeys.
- Placing big buildings feels clunky on low ground due to FPS view.

Although the game is great with diversity in buildings there is a major issue currently.
There is no way to alter terrain like flattening, raising or digging.
Half the time your buildings are clipping through terrain.
Building to make it look good is a massive pain due to the way building from first person is rather slow (especially when the buildings are big).
This really becomes an issue when placing floors/walls.
You constantly have to stack floors on top of each other (and for performance, remove the bottom floor) in order to elevate floors enough to not clip through ground.
For those like me who have OCD lining things up neatly this requires way too much patience and mind you i have quite the patience when it comes to building games.
Also there seems to be a lack of endemic life at the moment, it really needs more for it to feel alive, more diversity in lifeforms as well.
Cannot recommend this until these issues have been addressed.
Some minor issues with being unable to assign tools to hotkeys and placing big buildings from ground level (mainly due to inability to alter terrain).

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Similar but different to Factorio in all the best ways. The 3D take comes with benefits and disadvantages, but the addictive building qualities are still there. The game is beautiful and runs very well for early access, but the game is early access so there are occassional concerns, but they have been very infrequent and nothing that has ruined game play experience for me thus far.

I'm one of those who found this game and thought it looked interesting but could not understand how it could be a fun premise. You just build a base, right? And then grind through tech trees by making stuff. Yes, but somehow, like Factorio, this game calls to your inner completionist self. Developing your own solution to making an efficient production line is so inviting and addictive, and clearly there are plenty out there who agree based on the player numbers of games like this, Factorio and Dyson Sphere Project (which is now on my short list of games to try next).

It's calming and satisfying at the same time. There are elements that are not smooth and I would like to see improved, such as building in 3rd person to make placement easier, and being able to automate or queue self crafting commands (or create tech to speed it up). And the logistics of belts is either not completely refined, or I may have missed some of the more advanced commands, but again they are still developing the game.

So far, the Dev rollout plan has been slow but methodical, and the updates contain large additions to content, they are hitting all the right ideas to add, so I think this game is on the right track. If it looks interesting, it's probably right up your alley.

Great game! I was hesitant to buy but I can say its worth the money. Something special about this game is that you never feel at a loss for what to do which I find common in other games once you've gotten to the end of your ideas at that time. Rather, I feel like I'm always behind trying to unlock the next piece of equipment before I unlock the one I have tasked. Mechanics are quite good especially with early access. (22 hours in and no remarkable bugs).

base building: I am the person that can only decide on the set up I want after placing it down and deleting it 100 times until it looks and flows just right... this game reduces all the time consuming monotony of breaking down a huge setup just to move it a few meters. The ability to resorb items and place them down instantaneously makes a huge difference (plus you don't lose you resources by doing it)

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This is a "AAA" title in the factory/automation world.

From building snaps, to multiple pathing styles for conveyors. This one takes everything Fcatorio started and kicks it up 3 notches, in FPS view!

Minimal xeno presence, and cute arachnophobia mode put this solidly in the exploration/build genre with no defense or fortification elements to worry about.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A most satisfying experience.

First of all, this game is very relaxing. You are not pressured in time, only in ressources that have to be found and exploited. You do it all on your own terms, no pressure for progression but your own. The only danger is the wildlife, but once you get some equipment and get the feel of it, it's not hard to deal with.

Basically, it's all about organization. You don't have to juggle with thermodynamic or fluid mechanics, only with extraction and transformation.

That being said, the game has many production lines who will merge into other production lines to keep you busy redesigning everything to your taste or you just deal with it and watch your conveyor spaghetti mess rise off the ground.

You start with just a miner and, soon enough, end up with a mutli level factory with kilometres of conveyor belts going in every directions. Fun to plan or just wing it.

As of update 4, it feels almost like a finished game: it's stable and has enough quality content to keep you busy for a while.

If you like those kind of games, this one might be a must have. For the pricing, tons of other games fall very short, but this one delivers.

Then you can enjoy your cup of joe.

In short:

148 dead aliens
12 030 metres conveyor belts
1 cup, 1 truck
100% would it again

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is at the crossroads between Minecraft, Factorio and No Man's Sky.

I have 4 distant factories out in the woods operating on their own and filling my base with precious goods through automated delivery truck routes. Those goods are being funneled into 3 separate local factories and becoming even more precious goods. I use those to venture out and make even more advanced remote facilities.

Every little effort I make in this game pays off immensely; the bigger my machine grows, the easier it is to move forward; and yet there's always something even bigger around the corner, driving me to get just a little bit more of this, a little bit more of that. Basically, I'm hooked...

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is a fantastically complex factory builder on the surface that ultimately feels empty and directionless as it fails to actually provide any motivation for building said factories in the first place. It's aimless and meandering, and apparently the reason to build is building itself.

Granted the game is in Early Access (has been for a very long time) and this very likely may change in the future - until then, I am only giving it a negative review because if the game were to stay in it's current state, it wouldn't be a very fulfilling or fun game. It lacks goals.

That said, the actual process of building factories is incredibly deep and well thought out, and continues to get better.

When the developer adds an actual purpose to all this building, I will change my review from negative to positive.

Graphics are really pretty, with a well designed world, UI is easy to navigate. Monsters can still be a challenge to deal with in the later stages, but don't impact gameplay hardly at all. Progress is basically player driven, and learn things by trying them out yourself. this makes improving in this game feel real and really makes you excited when you learn new techniques to improve automation.
For new players, Space is key to making big factories. lay concrete platforms and walls to plan for massive expansion always. Multi-floor factories are generally the way to go.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Note: I hardly ever review games, but this game is great and deserves a review.

This game is absolutely amazing. It's in early access, so there will be bugs. However, so far, I have not discovered a single bug while playing this game. This game runs great, looks amazing, and works extremely well. I cannot recommend this enough. This is one of those games where, even if this type of game isn't for you, you cannot ignore the amount of work put into it. This game is a masterpiece.

What I like:
-------------
Floors can be built inside and overlap each other
Multiple hotbar levels, 10 spots in each level, 10 levels (can have more with upgrades, i think)
Mostly a building game, but the combat and exploration are amazing as well
There's so much in this game. This turns into that which turns into 9 other things which each turn into something else.
Automation go brrrrrr
Ridiculously huge maps to explore
Multiple map types (desert, flats, snow)

What I don't like:
-------------------
nothing. seriously, after sitting here for about 5 minutes thinking about what's wrong with this game, I cannot find a single bad thing about it.

Extremely great game. Never thought I'd enjoy a game like this (I'm a pvp type of guy. Rust, tarkov, ya know, those games).

Is it worth a buy? Yes. Buy it now, even if it's not on sale. This game is worth every penny of it's full price.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
2.5 years after getting that fat epic paycheck, game is still very much unfinished. A lot of in-game objects marked as WIP (work in progress). My base spawned next to deadly alien structures, that according to wiki cannot be touched for now, even in the end-game.
Building clipping is out of this planet. You can build splitters/mergers inside of buildings, which means you'll be unable to connect belt to them. Belts however, can easily go through each other.
No build assist mode - you play as regular sized human and you place building 3x your height with no way of seeing behind them. This causes you to rebuild 3-4 times before you finally line up input with output properly.
Some of issues I had seems to be poor design and I don't believe they will be fixed through EA.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I enjoy playing sandbox games quite a lot and satisfactory falls under that same category. I will put this out at the start of this review, I do enjoy this game whenever I play it, I think that there are a lot of things this game does well and every new update there is a plethora of things to explore and the polish of those features seem pretty decent for an early access game.

With that being said, I cannot recommend this game due to how boring it gets very quickly.

The game has very shallow depth for a game that it wants to be. Sandbox games usually allow you to build on your own level of depth you want the game to have, however the clear lack of tools and building options to do so it comes as no surprise that you can only arrange the same foundations a couple of times till you become bored of doing so. There is only 1 map and no map editor for community to create it's own maps, in my opinion a game like this should natively support some kind of editor tool to allow you to create your own maps, have some kind of expansion past the initial map or generate a random map every game, that way no game feels ever the same. On top of it, the progression system is very linear, with an attempt at creating a tech tree through MAM it still does not give you any options to go past, something I'd like to see is some kind of missions to complete rather than following the same format that milestone system follows.

I know this may came off a bit as harsh, however I really hope I can change this review as the time goes on and wish that the game keeps improving and keeps filling a lot of the void there is in the game.

Wow this game is hyper addictive. I am only up to Tier 4 at the moment and it literally is a bottomless pit of logic puzzles and figuring out how to maximize efficiency. Once you have a working factory it is extremely satisfying and I often catch myself just watching the factory in action and seeing the parts come off the line. Highly recommend.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory isn't a game. Satisfactory is an addiction. Of all the crafting games I've played, none have blended enjoyment, management, discovery, and beauty as well as this. Typically, this genre tends to overwhelm with a lack of guidance, and an over reliance on tedium. Satisfactory is vast (probably way more than I'm anticipating having only played for 10 hours at the time of this recommendation) and there are tedious elements, but the systems allow you to go at your own pace. There aren't (to my knowledge) bad guys that come out at night and ruthlessly destroy all you've been working on. Satisfactory is about efficiency, and the continuous nagging thought of "how can I be manufacturing this stuff quicker and easier? How can I make this automation work for me?" Yeah. It's a great game, and the complexity of the systems really make you think. There doesn't seem to be a true failure state. Machines don't break down, you don't have to keep your engineer fed or watered, deconstruction of a structure doesn't hurt you or leave you resource-less; it's simply a race against yourself. Maybe this all changes the deeper into the game you get, but after 10 hours, I can't recommend Satisfactory enough. Try it! Even if you're someone like me that tends to be overwhelmed and annoyed by other games in the genre.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Conclusion: The game is good but wait because of possible technical difficulties (crashes, delay on client side).

Functionally speaking the game is good. It is obviously like factory and if you liked that game but you can stomach a little more chaos, then this a good game for you.

I would not recommend this game at this moment because of sometimes unplayable delay on client side and CONSTANT (every session) crashes, ending with the unreal crash reporter and it necessitating a restart of the PC in most cases. It can even cause other games not to start anymore.

If that does not happen on your system, then great and more power to you. I am sure you will get the price worth of game out of this one. Yet, for me this game left a sour taste in my mouth.

I think it would be bold to hide behind "early access" after such a long development time when it comes to such general technical issues, so whether you think this will be better in the future is up to you.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game's awesome. The choices you make when designing your factory impact how you'll be interacting with the world and what challenges you'll face moving forward. Many transportation options and building blocks allow you to customize your factory in interesting and expressive ways. This means that even for long-distance operations, you don't necessarily need to use the same solution every time and you can get really creative with how you choose to play. The world is sweet and just keeps going. There are many biomes and the use of verticality and scale is pretty magnificent. The atmosphere of the game is nice, the UI and all the factory blocks are pretty once you get used to the scale of them. The exploration aspect of the game rewards you for looking around while the combat and environmental hazards add stakes to the experience.

Building a factory in this game is about more than making things: it's about how you choose to interact with the world to succeed, and there are no wrong answers.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
First of all, you must approve the data collection agreement before you can play the game. Otherwise, you cannot play. This is forbidden if you only want to play the game. You must consent to data collection about you for the game you purchased. For this reason, it deserved to get a negative vote.

Negative features:
1. There is no goal in the game. There is nothing but technological progress and production. In Factorio, you can fight with alien creatures that are constantly getting stronger and spread on the planet and you can have fun by producing different war vehicles.

2. Weapon types are very bad and inadequate.

3.No heavy weapons (tanks, helicopters, planes, artillery)

4. No active server creation. You can only work with an invitation. Don't buy if you dream of big servers. You cannot set up a professional server or connect because it is not available. In short, the game is single player.

5. The map is not unlimited. It will take a very large island limited.

6. Ridiculous: The resources are endless. This is not realistic, just like a children's game. It should have been a game about running out of resources and researching the environment for different resources.

7. The number of scientific researches is extremely low.

8. There are no blueprints for building duplication and setting up huge facilities. You have to do everything one by one or install mods.

9. So:
Factorio = Protein / Satisfactory = Fructose syrup
Factorio = Sun / Satisfactory = Moon
Factorio = Thorium / Satisfactory = Calcium
Factorio = Strong state / Satisfactory = Village

You have a long way to go.

Positive features:

1. 3D

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I love this game, and this is why.

I've spent a lot of my life gaming and this game stands out to me on so many levels. The reason for this, I think, is the wide range of talents of the people responsible for creating it. You can be smart without being particularly talented, you can be talented without being particularly creative, you can be creative without being funny. To be all of those, and have enough empathy, care and insight to place the player in the center, is incredibly rare. This is what this game does, it embodies all of that. You feel it when you play. It's full of jokes, mindboggling landscapes, otherworldly plants, creatures and structures.

So much of the game industry is about tricking players into playing games that aren't that fun. They do it by psychological tricks, by creating habits (offering daily and random rewards, each having their own psychological hook) and sure, they have players. But are the players happy while playing the game? Most producers don't seem to care. The creators of this game do, and it shows. Every gorgeous landscape, every joke, every little treasurehunt is an adventure with the player in focus. The game is created with love and with joy and you can just feel it when you play. You pick one bacon agaric plant next to some mountain and then you see another one, following the trail of baconcrumbs into a cavernous miniadventure. There are hundreds, maybe thousands of these all over the map. It makes me feel like it's the person that is valued, not the purse. I feel like my experience is key to everything the creators put in and I'm not used to that. It's a wonderful feeling.

But overall a really good game if you want to lay back and kill some time. Also try and organize it'll help you in the long run.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is one of my favorites for sure. The sense of discovery is quite magical; and the pacing and balance of the game feels very rewarding. Plus the lizard doggos are the cutest, not to mention the little factory cart (which is even more silly because it is incredibly hard to drive)!

I find the world charming, the way you are treated by your faceless superiors is comparable to how people are treated in The Outer Worlds. The art is vivid and absolutely gorgeous, especially in the "easier" desert. Something i found interesting is that it is just one big map, and picking before you start is simply deciding how much you want to struggle in the beginning/ where you want to be located. If you like Minecraft, you will absolutely adore this game for sure; it scratches a similar itch, but more focused in its goals.

The fauna in this game are interesting to me, i mentioned the "lizard doggo" before, but there is also a land whale that walks on stilted legs, and if you step on it, it is bouncy like a jump pad. There are also fire spitting rhinos and boars that headbutt you, as well as fireflies the size of volleyballs, and jumping spiders that can be replaced with cute cat heads, with arachnophobia mode on. There is very little to say negatively about this game to be honest. My only "problem" with this game (not really a problem) is that when you are playing multiplayer, if your partner quits, their body just stands there idly wherever they were when they quit; the same thing happens every update too where you respawn and it leaves a random character wherever you were standing when you last saved. Though i am pretty sure they fixed that.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
To say this game is incredibly well-balanced would be a pretty large understatement.

In general, the art style, music, and humor are EXACTLY what I wanted in this masterpiece without having any expectations to begin with. The world feels rich and pulls me to explore even though there's comparatively less content than in many open world games. Sometimes I'll see a resource like 5000m away and make a plan to connect it to my factory just because I know I'll have a lot of fun figuring out how any one of 10 ways I want to do it.

The moment I knew I was hooked was when I was about 15ish hours in and suddenly my power went out while adding to my copper refinery group. Got some fuel for the reserve biomass burners, flipped the switch, then boom, off again? Ohhh, I added too many power draws, let's make a few more burners! But wait, now my factory lost synchronization because the coal going to the hydro generators was being pulled from 2000m away, so now I can't get enough power to run the extractors to get the coal! Let's add a container in-line to store the coal and act as a capacitor for when I get it going again. Meanwhile, I set up 5 burners on a separate circuit to power the coal extractors and some other basic functions, now I need lots of biofuel! That should work! OH WAIT, I'M OUT OF BIOFUEL. Let's go "borrow" some alien carapaces to get a quick jump. Ok, got that, split the fuel between the burners, coal is now being pulled in for the hydro generators.

You really have to keep an eye on things, the game is SO engaging and makes you plan ahead as best you can, only to realize every time you add something that you need to re-configure a preexisting group of machines to work better with your modifications, or you need more of a certain resource since you started more advanced production, or you need to travel thousands of meters just to get the one oil resource within a 10min drive, or you need to venture out to find new technology in the wilderness, or any of a hundred other aspects to manage. I can't wait to start all over again when the full game releases.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Survival/craft spin:
Heavy focus on building and automation of manufactured goods.
Very light combat, exploration, narrative and goals.

Seemingly endless possibilities for base expansion and complexity could potentially provide many gameplay hours.

Runs surprisingly well considering all the complex structures that start adding up.

My only concern is lack of content and incentive to build elaborate bases. As with any crafting game, you will eventually question the time investment and tedium.

I think if it had a clear and defined goal and endgame, it would have more staying power. I'm struggling to justify 100s of hours to streamline everything without any kind of payoff.
I just simply can't click for hoyrs on emd without a carrot to chase.

Great game. It just needs to do a better job of motivating the player to continue.

Very fun. No real penalty other than "downtime" so there's no real pressure to get out of your comfort zone too quickly. The exploration is fun, resources don't seem too stingy so it's not like you're forced out into a world too quickly. A few unique weapons make the aliens not that difficult but be careful around cliffs. The knockback some have is nasty and can send you flying with a ton of time to think about it before you die. Very fun game once the mechanics start to click. Open world base builder factory stuff and it feels so good to see those items zipping along the belts! The youtube community is great too, there are a few dudes doing really good guides and builds to get you looking at things in a different light. Very fun game! It's a creative chill time sink :)

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I have barely scratched the surface, but I think this game is already in my top 10 all time list. The amount of satisfying progression and the wonderful interpretation of seeing your own factory in action is something that only Tekkit classic could replicate, and Satisfactory excels even beyond that. Fun game play, thought-provoking mechanics, and creating your own world while encouraging exploration make this game one of the best I have ever played. Early Access does limit some of its possibilities, but it is still on pace to being one of the best sandbox/management games ever.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is amazing. If you're a fan of open world, survival, crafting, and idle games this game is perfect. One of my biggest issues with this genre of games is inventory management, redundant crafting of older recipes, and continually having to harvest resource. Since the focus of this game is automation mining can be done automatically, crafting can be done automatically, and conveyor belts move the items to a storage contain. You still have to manage your ever expanding personal inventory but it's so much less daunting. The survival aspect isn't overly challenging but if you go too far things will kill you if you don't have decent weapons. Not having my infrastructure damaged by time or monsters is also so nice. I don't want to play a constant repair game. Once you've stabilized power you can treat this game like an idle game and leave it running to continue crafting. To progress in the game you'll need to export the wilds for new resources and it's a really good balance. I really hope future update do not ruin the great balance this game currently has.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
First of all this is a great game!

At the first try i could walk ingame but not look around. Took some time and several tries to fix the problem via .exe file-properties. Same problem, the way i fixed it before didnt fix it now, it took 2 evenings of frustration till i got it to work. OK i started a new world, better planned then first time, played some hours, got coal working, then random small update appears... mouse stuck AGAIN... several days later i solved the problem... getting rid of anti virus solved it xD
early access can be a pain sometimes

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Despite being in Early Access, this game offers a really nice looking world where you conduct research, gather resources and design supply lines to improve your systems. It has a lot of potential, and it feels in the sweet spot where you needn't have a PhD in Logistics to make a decent production chain, but it isn't a braindead grinding simulator. If you enjoyed games like Space Engineers, Factorio and the likes you will get instantly hooked to it.

The thing that surprised me the most and made me felt that most other games lack is an Arachnophobia mode, which prevents me from screaming and throwing my headphones away every single time a spider comes to give me a hug. It might be a minor detail, but the devs really hit the nail on these small things.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
The game so far isn't bad. Graphics are decent, audio needs more work, the complication is really awesome, but there is not enough actual independent building and some mechanics feel backwards. You don't get the floor or walls until the HUB is past level 0. Personally, I would like the walls and floors before then so I can plan my building and not have to redo a ton of things. I wished the building mechanic was more in line with Space Engineers where you have to build everything piece by piece. Feels like there isn't enough of a threat either. But, it's fun. Build, Transport materials, smelt, store, construct/assemble, etc.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
For Early Access this game is very impressive. Sometimes it's polished enough that it's easy to forget that it's EA and you try to build a working train station and within hours wish very bad things on basically everyone in the known universe, having sent 3 months salary directly to the swear jar while making notes of words and phrases you will have to try and explain to your children in a way that will not terrify them or scar them for life. Or you could play the game in its entirety without using any train mechanics and you'll be a happier and less mentally anguished person for it.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Since the release of Update 4, the color pallet seems to have shifted. Now the colors seem to be darker/warmer, and now I can't play the game for more than 5 minutes without getting a headache. I was curious if it was just me, but after asking several friends about this, they all are experiencing it as well. I'm not sure if this is something the developers are aware of, but until then I won't be playing anymore. I also lost a save of 50+ hours after the update, not too happy about that either. The game was fun and addicting, but once you reach around tier 5 or 6 the game just seems tedious and repetitive. It pains me to give this game a bad review, because it is beautiful and fun, but as of right now the cons outweigh the pros.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
The most addicting game I have ever played in my life. Losing hours of sleep and time was something I thought would never come back like when I was younger. I remember the first time I played Command and Conquer and playing all the way through the night. Or that time I was introduced to Civilization and realized one more turn actually lasted till dawn. Since then, I have played a lot of games. I love all types of games.

This game is some other animal. It is strategy, progression and a sense of accomplishment that many games cannot master. It is fun beyond belief. When I saw the trailer, I had no idea how conveyor belts could be exciting. Then the game launches, then you start to play, and then hours of time disappear.

I introduced my friend to this, and he started and now cannot stop as well. We stopped playing Valheim (another great game) since this enter our lives. We played multiplayer, which is a lot of fun to do this game as two.

Look, this is a great game. This is well thought out and so unique. Fantastic and well worth the time and money. The fact that this is not complete adds even more excitement to the coming content of this game and I have barely cracked it.

Life is short, but this game is worth your time in life.

Not usually my type of game. It took a few short play sessions to get into it, due to my brain overheating trying to set up efficient factories. Having long conveyors from ore nodes to more centralized locations really help, it seems not worth it at first but you only have to build it once. Then you tear it all down and build it better, rinse and repeat. Lots to upgrade and research, huge maps, chill overall. If you like making things efficient, and don't mind flexing your brain a bit this game can be fun. Although you have to be in the mood for it.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is an amazing hit game for me. It for sure has that Factorio feel, but also grabs that Modded Minecraft Industrial feel as well. I'm not always the best at it, but you can build extremely high vertically. The world map is insane as well. Many people when they first started this game they use to think that there was 3 maps (3 starting area's before the desert update) because of how big it is for a game like this. Now there is 4 wonderful start area's and tons of fun.

I can't wait for Dedicated Servers and I really really hope they will consider allowing team / separate progression.

If you enjoyed Modded Tech Minecraft, Factorio, FortressCraft Evolved, Dyson Sphere Program, and Many others I think you will love Satisfactory!

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
A fun factory-building game, the bright visuals and 3D construction as well as the exploration aspects have helped me get much more into this game than Factorio. It's not a competition, but if you bounced off of that one as I did you may like this.

Additionally there's still a lot of content to come and the modding community is great.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It is stunning to see how far Satisfactory has come over the years. And it will go further.

The game does many things very well.

Building in Satisfactory just WORKS. Everything fits together nicely, which is really great because I get kinda OCD. I have had no small amount of headaches when building in some other games, so it is really a Satisfying experience.

You can tear down everything at no penalty (you get back the full amount of resources you used to build), which is really great when you're experimenting new ideas or just trying to get things in the right position.

And you have full control over the way you want to build your factory; spaghetti, organised, or somewhere in between.

It also gives me a great, yet perhaps slightly strange, sense of pleasure to run around sliding under conveyor belts. IT COMPLETES ME.

------------------------------------------------------------

I love how calming and peaceful the game is because I can chill for hours on end, building my factory and optimising production lines and layouts.
Not having this imminent danger at the back of my head that hordes of creatures are approaching to destroy my hard work.

Yet, that doesn't mean there isn't any combat. In fact, conflict with the fauna (and flora...?) can get rather intense while you're out and about. Rest assured, there are really neat weapons and equipment.

Exploring is also a huge part of the game, which is why it's so awesome to have a breathtaking world with many biomes to be in awe of while exploring the expansive map (30 square kilometres).

------------------------------------------------------------

Side progression content, like research trees, adds more layers to an already immensely deep game.
I'm always unlocking new stuff, like parts that can be used to make my factory look even cleaner and more Satisfying.

I really appreciate the details in the game as well.
The animations are so magnificent (like the Space Elevator's, for one) and the sound effects are very fitting.
Building and item designs look great and the music is very relaxing.

You can't really see your own character at this point, especially in single player, but I know a lot of work has gone into the character design and I wish we could appreciate it more.

------------------------------------------------------------

There's a whole ton of content and features yet to come, and bugs to be fixed, but Coffee Stain is passionately working on the game.

They are such a chill group of devs, and I love watching their Youtube channel because you can see how real they are, and learn about how they make the game (especially from the Developer Highlights).
It is also rare to see Community Managers that are as engaged as Jace and Snutt are.

------------------------------------------------------------

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
It's ... satisfactory (pun intended).

Game initially has a very ARK and Subnautica feel to it - you're on your own (you against the world), running around and slowly grabbing every resource you can by hand. Then you start unlocking various tiers of tools and mechanisms to upscale and automate this process to be able to unlock further tiers with better tools and mechanisms, Graphics are beautiful. The game doesn't hold your hand and doesn't spoonfeed you how to build your factory - during tutorial you are taught the basics of how to use your tools and how to gather resources, the rest is up to you. That means if you don't start building your factory lines as soon as you receive the blueprints, you'll be running around for an hour forth and back manually gathering resources and processing them by hand, all the while thinking to yourself: "there's gotta be a faster way of doing this" - the game is called "Satisfactory" ... you're suppose to build automated lines not fetch everything by hand. However, if you don't like building factories or tweaking your conveyor lines... you might not enjoy this. There's a research table, which allows you to unlock stuff through exploration and research by feeding research projects components like alien animals and various plants but overall the exploration feels rather limited, because again, this is "Satisfactory" and not "Exploratory".

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I saw some complaints regarding the multiplayer connectivity on this game that I want to address before the rest of my review, for those of you who only enjoy this kind of game with friends:

Although I have only played 3 relatively short sessions with the same person so far, I can report that the only bugs/issues encountered on either side were general desync, such as the joiner initially having bushes/trees that appear harvest-able but are no longer on the map for the host. This however resolved itself quickly upon leaving the vicinity of the 'ghost assets' and returning, which removes those assets. Apart from this, the joiner will find it slightly more difficult to hit enemies due to split-second delays in attacks compared to the host. Bearing in mind that the devs have a disclaimer on the Multiplayer saying that it is buggier than Solo, I would say that the online is functioning very well. (My issues were observed on a long distance connection between Eastern US and Southern Africa)

Moving on to the rest of the game, this is a real gem. I've spent just as much time crafting, building, optimising and completing missions as I have spent exploring, admiring the scenery and watching my machinery and production lines work. This game is not only entertaining and well developed, but also just plain satisfying, as the name itself implies (as well as the endless "this game is Satisfactory" jokes I've made to my partner).

There is never any time pressure. Its up to you what you want to do and when you want to do it. Even the how is almost 100% up to you and your vision.

To go into detail would make this review way too long. If you are at all interested in the concepts of Industry & Production and building fabrication plants exactly the way you want, get this game without hesitation.
