EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
So I think it's only fair that I revisit this since I have since put in another 90 hours since my first review (and I think I'm addicted). I must admit I judged too soon and I have left my original review up for reference. If you want the short answer, yes I think it's worth the purchase but read on for why.

My original problem turned out to be my own failures. The game is not easy, in fact I would say it suffers from a classic pitfall in this type of game: the learning cliff. But that said I wouldn't change it, because I hate games that hold your hand too much. In fact in retrospect this game does a great job to hold your hand just enough to not be annoying on additional playthroughs yet still let you fail by your own stupidity.

Designing a production line is frustrating, complicated, and yet amazingly rewarding process. (prepare to ask "where did the last 4 hours go"?). Unlocking new toys is fun as hell! Realizing you unlocked something amazing and can't build it until you go find a bunch of new stuff is super annoying (in that I get to go search for stuff and die trying way), but wait there's more!

Being chased by scary ass giant freaking spiders will probably induce nightmares (there's an arachnophobe mode which changes the sprites, thanks devs but I like my adrenaline injections)! You will learn the sounds of some mobs and reflexively jump to avoid their attack. Oh and even though it doesn't kill stuff there is no end to the fun of running over above mentioned mobs with your dune buggy thing. Yes I have parked the vehicle on top of them to keep them from attacking me, this is a viable tactic.

Ultimately I would say buy the game if you have $25 to spend (at time of writing) and love these types of crafting exploring games. But do be aware that there are bugs, some of them can be fun, others annoying. However I haven't seen a truly game breaking bug yet, so for early access at this price point it's a great game so far.

P.S. If you're like me and struggling, go find the wiki and an online map to help you out. It may feel a bit like cheating but even on my second play through I am finding the wiki very helpful!


Original Review:

Honestly I wanted to love this game. And on a level I do love it, which is why it pains me to say no right now. Ultimately I love this type of builder game, I loved Factorio for example, however I hated resource depletion in that game. I had thought maybe this game turned it into 3d and ditched that, which it did. BUT, the problem is power generation. There are no other depletion mechanics but after a short period I found myself constantly maintaining power generators. I want to love this game, and on a level I do, but I also want this game to be more of a sandbox than it is. It is for this reason that I at this moment I can't so solidly "yes buy it". I do hope given the early access status that the game will catch up.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
TLDR: A generally chill, graphics card breaking, factory builder on a beautiful alien world with satisfyingly tight mechanics and, that is kind of it?

LONGER: It is a 3D factory builder which has put a heavy emphasis on logistics and exploitation of resources, a secondary emphasis on exploration and a nearly non-existent emphasis on combat. Do not expect a factorio style alien assault. That being said, what it does choose to focus on, is executed superbly. Controls for building are straight forward enough, logistics setup seems fairly intuitive and the research aspect really gets you out there to explore a very beautiful and fairly varied alien landscape. The music is pretty damn good as well.

That being said, the games requirements can totally place a choke hold on your PC, depending on your settings and the combat is very rudimentary. Its very clear that it was never really the focus but, generally speaking it does not feel great so, if you are here for combat for some reason, this one wont do it for you. Its more of a grim necessity than something to revel in.

Overall, have a chill time, build some factories and, plow a wonderful natural wonder of a world into a concrete jungle of most efficient resource exploitation!

YOU CANNOT PAUSE THIS SINGLE-PLAYER GAME. Because ♥♥♥♥ you.

I died three times completing the very first objective. Why? The markers were WAY off from the objective and were underground. I had to go watch a video of the game to figure out what the hell to do. (The markers felt entirely uncorrelated with the objective.) Instead of refunding the game as I should have, I persisted -- seemingly because I wanted to encounter the same or similar issues ad infinitum. For people interested in having any clue as to what they should do next, this game is best described as a bookmark-the-Wiki simulator.

You advance the game by finding new items in the world. The most recent two items I found are "WIP" and explicitly state they don't do anything.

Let me say it again: YOU CANNOT PAUSE THIS SINGLE-PLAYER GAME.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Satisfactory is just epic survival / crafting based game. The amount of content in-game is just great. I am playing coop world and after 22 hours we are I would say in about 35% of the game unlocked. But that doesn't mean we are in 35% of what game has to offer.
The game mechanics are really nice and everything has its purpose.
Until now I didn't find an item without a purpose. Even green slime something can be use for research.

However, if you want to play in coop, you will experience quite large amount of bugs. Usually its like small visual bugs. But sometimes it can be quite annoying. For example host sees the storage system one way and the person joining into the session can see only half of it. This is something that can be fixed by couple of restarts but its still quite annoying. The game is in early access and if you're starting a multiplayer session it alerts you that multiplayer "is far from finished"

Overall I would say its one of the best survival / crafting based games I played.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
We had two stacks of Iron ore, seventy-five pallets of Steel beams, five slugs of high-powered sparky power, a Tractor half-full of Quartz, and a whole galaxy of multi-colored Beryl nuts, Paleberries, Bacon agaric, Mycelia… Also, a quart of Crude oil, a quart of water, a case of Polymer resin, a pint of Heavy oil residue, and two dozen solid Biofuels. Not that we needed all that for the construction, but once you get locked into a serious workbench manufacturing, the tendency is to push it as far as you can. The only thing that really worried me was the Uranium waste. There is nothing in the world more helpless and irresponsible and depraved than a man in the depths of an Uranium waste run, and I knew we’d get into that rotten stuff pretty soon.

10/10

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
This game is simply delightful. I find planning out factory layouts to be very relaxing, almost meditative, and watching all the parts flow through a newly built production line is... well, satisfying. You are never pressured to build faster, or bigger, or better - it's all up to you and how you want to pace yourself. I was also pleased to find that the combat (and death) is a lot less punishing than the initial trailers made it out to be. Highly recommended if you at all like logistics, resource management sims, research trees, exploring, or just sitting idly and watching your hard work pay off.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
The key to enjoyment in this game is in the name: satisfaction

I started off building randomly with no particular organisation, which lead to a tangled spaghetti of conveyor belts and production lines that were either backed up with goods or had no goods at all. For a while this was okay, my factory was a mess but it was MY mess. I knew where everything was and it was fun to navigate around, but when it came to progression there was the common issue of figuring out where to even start. Trying to figure out how to weave a new production chain into the mess was like trying to untangle cables at the back of a pc, or staring at a power extension cord with six other extension cords plugged in. Most of the time I would rather delete all of my conveyors and start over rather than try fixing them.

'decision paralysis' is something you may run into a lot whilst playing this. Knowing whats needed to be done but feeling crushed by the effort it will take to implement it. Looking at the production line for an Assembly Director System will be daunting for anyone, but attempting it is a lot harder with a messy system.

The only way to get through this was to start organising properly, first by creating dedicated 'highways' for stacks of conveyors, making sure they are all the same height and getting rid of diagonals and weird bends - sticking to just right angle turns and straight lines. This made it so much easier to expand, and it was to clean up my mess. Honestly, putting down the space elevator and watching the animation for the first time is great - but turning a complicated tangle of 10 different conveyors into a neat hub and seeing all the goods moving along smoothly?

Also, research the Xeno-Basher asap, do not torture yourself by sticking with the Xeno-Zapper for longer than you need to otherwise research will feel like a horrible grind.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
For people who already played Factorio:

Satisfactory is very fun, but it's not just a 3d version of Factorio. There is a much higher focus on exploration, intermediate product chains, and building for aesthetics and less focus on 'pure' logistics, maximizing throughput, and large scale transportation of resources. Enemies in Satisfactory also don't ever attack your base; they are only out in the world to make exploration more challenging (I personally prefer it this way). These different focuses aren't a bad thing. It just prioritizes different parts of the larger "logistics game" experience compared to Factorio.

If you liked Factorio for the puzzle of figuring out how to chain the different machines together to create a final product or if you liked building a cool base, you will probably like Satisfactory even more.

If you instead liked Factorio because of the logistics challenge of managing resources across the map, of connecting multiple full-throughput factories, and because of the oh-so-satisfying train mechanics, you may not find Satisfactory to be as satisfactory (see what I did there?).

It's not that Satisfactory doesn't have these mechanics, but they are either de-prioritized in the overall gameplay experience or only introduced to the player very late into the game. Trains are the clearest example of this, being available in Factorio as soon as you unlock steel and allowing you to completely change the way that you approach factory design going into the mid-game towards a more decentralized system of sub-factories with a number of advantages (and some disadvantages). Satisfactory has similar rail mechanics but they are a end-game technology that you only gain access to once you are all but done with the macro-level design of your base. You either have to explicitly plan to have trains early on, and sacrifice efficiency to work over large distances before you unlock them, or you build everything pretty close together the whole time and you never really find yourself needing trains unless you plan on building a full on late game mega base.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Early access game but seems quite well made. Pretty relaxing game as well, there are creatures that attack you but they are not very numerous which means you can build your factory in peace. Lots of crafting and tiers to advance and unlock more. Quite addicting - and what is nice is you can walk away from the computer and let your factory do the work.

Eating food restores health if you are injured but other than that there's no need to keep eating. I enjoy this because you don't spend time grinding to stock up food and worry about losing health. Graphics are very good in my opinion. Controls are smooth and you don't lose any resources when you delete things you've built.

Overall I'd recommend the game. It's low stress and will keep you entertained for many many hours.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
Multiplayer has improved significantly with Update 4. Desync issues appear to have been fixed as far as I can tell. I used to see my friend running in place (desync) but now that does not happen after this update.

Get this game, and especially if you have friends to build a factory with. Exploring the alien planet, building your factory, and reaching milestones is satisfying and the tech that you unlock is amazing.

I unlocked the Hoverpack this evening and it is so much better than the fuel-required Jetpack; at least around the factory. Hoverpack requires that you need to be near your power grid. There is still plenty to unpack in this update and I will keep playing as I've already put 80(!!!) hours into this game.
